Gains by the dollar and a broad retreat in commodities prices kept pressure on U.S. stocks heading into afternoon trade Thursday, as markets continued to react to Wednesday's rate policy decision from the Federal Reserve.The S&P 500 dipped furthest, down 0.9%. The Dow shed 0.8% and the Nasdaq showed an 0.7% loss. Pressure on small caps continued, with the Russell 2000 down 1%.Volume upshifted to track about 8% higher on both the NYSE and Nasdaq exchanges.The stock market today had given back effectively all of the gains from Wednesday's rally. Both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 hung at the bottom of the session's trading range. The Nasdaq was retesting support at its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 had dropped below its 50- and 200-day lines.In stocks, life insurance, gold and ore miners and oil-related groups posted the worst losses among industries at midday. Mining and oil-related stocks held the five worst losses among S&P 500 stocks.Refiners were a different story, with Marathon Petroleum (MPC) climbing 4% to the best gain on the index.FedEx (FDX) grabbed the index's second best advance, up 3% after delivering strong fiscal second quarter results late Wednesday.Beaten-down 3D printer maker 3D Systems (DDD) surged 9%, bumped up by an upgrade to overweight from equal weight by Stephens & Co. Peer Stratasys (SSYS) jumped 5%.About 80% of the IBD 50 stocks traded lower. China-based asset manager Noah Holdings (NOAH) and Grupo Financiero Galicia (GGAL) continued to lead the list, up about 4% each.

Stock futures pecked out moderate gains ahead of Thursday's open, weakening after data showed a slowdown in Philadelphia region manufacturing. Dow futures traded 31.9 points above fair market value, nearly halving their hour-earlier gain. Nasdaq 100 futures eased to a 18.9-point gain, and S&P 500 futures were up 2.4 points — less than half their earlier levels.

If overseas markets are any indictor, the stock market today may continue yesterday's reaction to the series of interest rate hikes initiated by the Federal Reserve. The Federal Open Market Committee voted to lift the federal funds rate by 0.25 percentage point, up from its 0%-0.25% range — the first increase in that rate since June 2006. The committee projected subsequent increases would lift the rate to 1.4% by the end of next year.
The FOMC strengthened its decision by raising the discount rate to 1% and lifted its interest paid on excess reserves and the rate on overnight reverse repo operations.

All this affects how banks manage cash and how quickly rates begin to reflect the Fed's target. FOMC members generally expect the fed funds rate to rise to 0.375% before the next increase, according to documents accompanying Wednesday's decision.

Technical stuff, but global markets liked it. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei jumped 1.6%, adding to its 2.6% rally Wednesday and putting the index back in positive territory for the week. China's Shanghai Composite popped 1.8% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index edged up 0.8%. In Europe, stocks rumbled higher, with Frankfurt's DAX up 3.3% near midday, the CAC-40 in Paris showing a 2.5% gain and London's FTSE 100 up a mere 1.5%.
The dollar rose. Oil prices took a ride — Brent crude up, West Texas Intermediate down, but just a fraction each. Metals and most agricultural commodities traded narrowly lower.

U.S. markets received a strong early dose of economic news today, starting with the Labor Department reporting a pullback in initial unemployment claims, to 271,000 in the week ended Dec. 12. That was almost 4% below the prior week's tally, but just short of consensus forecasts for 270,000 claims. The four-week moving average eased to 270,500 — its first slip in three weeks.

Mid-Atlantic region manufacturing weakened this month, with the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's Manufacturing Business Outlook Survey slipping to -5.9, down from a positive 1.9 tally in November. Economists had expected a mild pullback to 1.2. The index's third decline in four months showed a drop in new orders and rising inventories, although shipments and employment improved.
The Conference Board reports its November Leading Indicators Index at 10 a.m. ET.
Dow stocks were generally positive, but gains were modest. 3M (MMM) once again led the index, up just over 1%.
The S&P 500 showed a diverse set of early risers.

FedEx (FDX) delivered a 5% premarket gain after reporting above-consensus earnings and revenue growth in its fiscal second-quarter report late Wednesday. The global parcel delivery giant is near lows in a six-month consolidation.
Chipmaker Micron Technology (MU) and refiner Valero (VLO) both grabbed 4% gains before the open.
Automotive undercarriage king Borg Warner (BWA) sat at the bottom of the index with a 3% loss.

Trade among leading stocks was subdued ahead of the open, with most IBD 50 stocks trading flat to higher. Constellation Brands (STZ), Dycom (DY) and Global Payments (GPN) all rose about 0.6% to top the list.
Constellation ended Wednesday in buy range, less than 3% above a 138.98 buy point in a flat base.
Dycom was back above an 80.95 buy point after erasing its initial gain above that buy point and diving through its 10-week line in strong trade, both sell signals.

Global Payments has sorting out to do after diving 8% in massive trade Wednesday on news of its $4.3 billion purchase of Heartland Payment Systems (HPY). The gap down shredded support at the stock's 10-week moving average and tripped a clear sell signal.Stock futures pecked out moderate gains ahead of Thursday's open, weakening after data showed a slowdown in Philadelphia region manufacturing. Dow futures traded 31.9 points above fair market value, nearly halving their hour-earlier gain. Nasdaq 100 futures eased to a 18.9-point gain, and S&P 500 futures were up 2.4 points — less than half their earlier levels.If overseas markets are any indictor, the stock market today may continue yesterday's reaction to the series of interest rate hikes initiated by the Federal Reserve. The Federal Open Market Committee voted to lift the federal funds rate by 0.25 percentage point, up from its 0%-0.25% range — the first increase in that rate since June 2006. The committee projected subsequent increases would lift the rate to 1.4% by the end of next year.The FOMC strengthened its decision by raising the discount rate to 1% and lifted its interest paid on excess reserves and the rate on overnight reverse repo operations.All this affects how banks manage cash and how quickly rates begin to reflect the Fed's target. FOMC members generally expect the fed funds rate to rise to 0.375% before the next increase, according to documents accompanying Wednesday's decision.Technical stuff, but global markets liked it. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei jumped 1.6%, adding to its 2.6% rally Wednesday and putting the index back in positive territory for the week. China's Shanghai Composite popped 1.8% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index edged up 0.8%. In Europe, stocks rumbled higher, with Frankfurt's DAX up 3.3% near midday, the CAC-40 in Paris showing a 2.5% gain and London's FTSE 100 up a mere 1.5%.The dollar rose. Oil prices took a ride — Brent crude up, West Texas Intermediate down, but just a fraction each. Metals and most agricultural commodities traded narrowly lower.U.S. markets received a strong early dose of economic news today, starting with the Labor Department reporting a pullback in initial unemployment claims, to 271,000 in the week ended Dec. 12. That was almost 4% below the prior week's tally, but just short of consensus forecasts for 270,000 claims. The four-week moving average eased to 270,500 — its first slip in three weeks.Mid-Atlantic region manufacturing weakened this month, with the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's Manufacturing Business Outlook Survey slipping to -5.9, down from a positive 1.9 tally in November. Economists had expected a mild pullback to 1.2. The index's third decline in four months showed a drop in new orders and rising inventories, although shipments and employment improved.The Conference Board reports its November Leading Indicators Index at 10 a.m. ET.Dow stocks were generally positive, but gains were modest. 3M (MMM) once again led the index, up just over 1%.The S&P 500 showed a diverse set of early risers.FedEx (FDX) delivered a 5% premarket gain after reporting above-consensus earnings and revenue growth in its fiscal second-quarter report late Wednesday. The global parcel delivery giant is near lows in a six-month consolidation.Chipmaker Micron Technology (MU) and refiner Valero (VLO) both grabbed 4% gains before the open.Automotive undercarriage king Borg Warner (BWA) sat at the bottom of the index with a 3% loss.Trade among leading stocks was subdued ahead of the open, with most IBD 50 stocks trading flat to higher. Constellation Brands (STZ), Dycom (DY) and Global Payments (GPN) all rose about 0.6% to top the list.Constellation ended Wednesday in buy range, less than 3% above a 138.98 buy point in a flat base.Dycom was back above an 80.95 buy point after erasing its initial gain above that buy point and diving through its 10-week line in strong trade, both sell signals.Global Payments has sorting out to do after diving 8% in massive trade Wednesday on news of its $4.3 billion purchase of Heartland Payment Systems (HPY). The gap down shredded support at the stock's 10-week moving average and tripped a clear sell signal.
The stock market remained lower in early afternoon trading Friday with indexes bogged down near session lows. The Nasdaq tumbled 1.1%, the S&P 500 1.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average 1.6%.
Volume was tracking sharply higher on a day of options and futures expirations, or quadruple witching. Declining stocks led advancers by nearly 2-to-1 on the NYSE and by 12-to-7 on the Nasdaq.

The Dow transportation average was down 2% in thestock market today. Air freight companies UPS (UPS) andFedEx (FDX) slid after the Seattle Times reported that Amazon.com (AMZN) is in talks to launch its own air cargo business.
The newspaper cited Amazon's frustration with third-party carriers such as UPS and FedEx.

One reason the Dow was off more than other indexes was because Boeing (BA) gapped down after an analyst downgrade. Wells Fargo downgraded the aerospace giant to market perform from outperform. The stock briefly lifted back above its 200-day moving average Thursday, only to fall below it Friday.

Macom Technology Solutions (MTSI) broke out of a cup-with-handle with a 38.69 buy point. Volume was well above average, a positive sign for the breakout. The developer of semiconductor devices mainly for Internet and military applications is in the IBD 50.

Red Hat (RHT) broke out of a flat base, although the stock quickly sank back into the pattern. The software developer's revenue and earnings for the November-ended quarter topped estimates. Guidance for the current quarter showed earnings below views but revenue above forecasts.The stock market remained lower in early afternoon trading Friday with indexes bogged down near session lows. UPS (UPS) CEO David Abney on Tuesday said potential plans by Amazon (AMZN)  to expand its own shipping capabilities were unlikely to significantly affect the global package-deliverer's pricing, an announcement that comes as the e-commerce giant grapples with higher shipping costs to meet demand for faster service.Abney's remarks came in response to an analyst question on UPS' Q4 earnings call about what effect Amazon's reported plans to lease Boeing (BA) cargo planes would have on competitive pricing in the U.S. and European express market."I didn’t read anything in the last quarter that we felt like is, on any kind of substantial basis, is going to affect our pricing in the market," Abney said.Amazon, UPS' biggest customer, has been trying to rein in shipping expenses and reduce its dependence on UPS, whose own delivery costs have risen over the years due to e-commerce growth and attempts to modernize its delivery system.The two companies have reportedly been at increasing odds with each other after 11th-hour Amazon holiday orders inundated UPS' delivery infrastructure, resulting in botched Christmas-season deliveries in 2013. UPS in 2014 placed volume caps on some retailers in 2014.While questions persist about the package deliverer's ability to handle surges in package volume, the company has expanded customers' abilities to track and reroute deliveries and choose where to pick them up. UPS' acquisition of Coyote Logistics also helped it manage transportation services and costs during the peak season.Shares of Amazon dropped after its Q4 earnings per share last week grew dramatically but missed analyst forecasts. Shipping costs rose during the quarter due as its Prime Now program, offering free two-day shipping, becomes more popular. Along with leasing jets, Amazon has taken a stake in at least one European delivery company and has begun using its own delivery trucks. And it wants, eventually, to deliver packages via drones.Still, Abney appeared to try to tamp down speculation of any tension between the companies."Amazon's a good customer of ours, we have a mutually beneficial relationship," he said during the call. "Our goal with Amazon or any other big customer is to continue to show our value though the integrated network and through our technologies and to have a value proposition that’s difficult to match. We do add capacity for large customers such as Amazon. We do it, though, when we’re sure we have the proper economic return.”And earlier in the call, he emphasized collaboration with customers and adjustments to its network to better handle holiday volume.“This year, our customers worked more closely with us than ever," Abney said. "And I want to thank them for making adjustments and being flexible.”Besides, the company's fourth-quarter results were strong. EPS jumped 26% to $1.57, soundly beating estimates for $1.42. Sales edged up to $16.1 billion, slightly missing forecasts.And the company guided 2016 diluted EPS of $5.70 to $5.90, well above an outlook for $5.73. UPS also guided revenue growth of 6% to 8%, above analysts expectations for 5% growth.UPS, which some see as a bellwether for the economy, also said the outlook for the global economy remained uncertain.Abney said the U.S.' gross domestic product outlook was muted in 2016 but was expected to gain strength in the second half of the year. The company also said it expected "slight improvements" in Europe and Asia's GDP, but that emerging markets would still be shaky.“Although the industrial side of the economy has slowed," Abney said near the beginning of the call. "The explosive growth of e-commerce continues to create great opportunity.”UPS shares rose 0.6% to 94.67  in the stock market today. Shares of rival parcel delivery service Federal Express (FDX) fell 1.6% to 130.15.

United Parcel Service (UPS) has just put another Christmas season behind it and, according to reports, it wasn't too bad. That contrasts with 2013, when the company struggled under a heavier-than-expected volume of merchandise shipped. It overcompensated the next year, but that ended up costing the company millions. When UPS announced the following January it would miss Q4 estimates, investors…

Amazon.com (AMZN) shares plunged in early trading Friday, after the e-commerce leader late Thursday fell well short of earnings estimates and also came up light on revenue.Earnings per share shot up 122% vs. a year earlier to $1 a share, excluding various items. But that didn't come close to views for $1.56 among analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Sales rose 22% to $35.7 billion, ending two quarters of accelerating growth and slightly missing forecasts for $35.98 billion. Revenue would have risen 26%, excluding foreign-exchange swings.Amazon.com stock was down 9.5% after the opening bell in the stock market today, near 575.Shares had closed up 8.9% to 635.54 in the regular session. The stock more than doubled in 2015, though like much of the rest of the market, it has struggled in January. As usual -- CEO Jeff Bezos has said that he will always put the customer before profits -- Amazon is spending heavily on its business, logging a 20.5% increase in operating costs to $34.6 billion.Bezos said in the earnings statement that 2015 was the first year the firm passed $100 billion sales and 300 million customers.Memberships in Prime, Amazon’s customer loyalty program which offers free two-day shipping and free video streaming among other services, grew 51%. Prime is one of the key drivers of the company’s core e-tail business.Prime has more than 50 million members in the U.S alone, according to Consumer Intelligence Research Partners.Compared with Amazon's fast-growing sales, eBay (EBAY), the largest U.S.e-commerce rival, posted lackluster sales growth during the holiday shopping season. EBay also offered lower-than-expected guidance for 2016. Shares plunged 12.5% on Thursday, though Wells Fargo analyst Matt Nemer says that the sell-off was too hasty.In Q4 2015 Amazon said that Amazon Web Services, its cloud computing division, hauled in $2.4 billion in revenue, up 69% over the year-earlier quarter. In the earnings statement, the company said AWS is now available across 12 geographic regions around the world and that it launched 722 significant new services in 2015.Several analysts have upped their price targets in recent weeks because of AWS's strong performance and potential for growth. Credit Suisse analyst Stephen Ju believes that the company’s capital expenditures in cloud computing are going to begin to decrease in the near future.It’s worth noting that the firm faces vigorous competition from Microsoft (MSFT) and Alphabet (GOOGL), which recently hired former VMWare (VMW) CEO Diane Greene to lead the consolidated team.Microsoft shares rose in after-hours action after the software giant reported better-than-expected results, led by its Azure cloud unit. Alphabet, which reports Monday, fell 1% late.Though many analysts are bullish because of AWS, others have begun to speculate that the company is going to get into the shipping business and compete with the likes of FedEx (FDX) and UPS (UPS). Amazon has announced the purchase of a fleet of trucks to ferry goods between fulfillment centers. It's also rumored to be running a cargo-flight operation out of Ohio, leasing 767 jets, and it's even getting into the ocean-shipping business.The thinking, according to several analysts, is similar to how Amazon got involved in cloud computing: As a result of the firm's own needs -- holiday web traffic surges require enormous data centers -- it eventually realized that it could sell excess capacity at a substantial profit. It's possible in the future that people may be able to "ship with Amazon.""I would say that what we’ve found, that to properly service our customers at peak, we need to supplement our partners' services," CFO Brian Olsavsky said on the call. "It’s not meant to replace them. Carriers are no longer able to handle it at peak. We’ve had to add some resources on our own."Amazon sees Q1 sales of $26.5 billion to $29 billion, or growth of 17% to 28%. The company does not offer EPS guidance but expects operating income of $100 million to $700 million, compared with $255 million a year earlier.Wall Street has forecast Amazon will earn 77 cents a share non-GAAP on revenue of $27.7 billion.

Tight-lipped Amazon.com (AMZN) says that during the holiday shopping season it experienced "record-breaking metrics" for its Prime loyalty program, company-made devices and original video content, according to a Monday press release. "(We) believe this will be our best holiday season ever," Amazon spokeswoman Katie McFadzean wrote to IBD in an email. McFadzean pointed to the company's public statement about its…

Stocks surged in the final hour of trading to boost the indexes to big gains after the Fed, as widely expected, raised interest rates by a quarter point. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each rallied 1.5%, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.3%.
Volume was mixed in the stock market today, higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq, according to early figures.
Fed Chief Janet Yellen said an improving labor market and other conditions had been met, and that tightening will be "gradual." It was the first rate hike since June 2006.

Solar, automakers and drug store retailers were among the day's top gainers, while oil and steel stocks were among the biggest decliners, as crude oil prices resumed their slide after two days of gains.

After the close, shares of FedEx (FDX) rose after the company reported fiscal Q2 earnings and revenue above estimates. The company also affirmed 2016 guidance. EPS came in at $2.58 vs. estimates of $2.51. Sales were $12.5 billion, above estimates of $12.43 billion.
Solar stocks soared amid news that Congress agreed to extend the solar investment tax credit through 2024. It's expected to vote Thursday or Friday.

First Solar (FSLR) soared 10%, gapping up past a 59.95 buy point in brisk trade. Solar City (SCTY) surged 34% to a four-month high, retaking its 200-day moving average with authority. SunPower (SPWR) leapt 14%, JinkoSolar (JKS) 8% and JA Solar (JASO) 6%, all in big volume.
Internet stocks rallied on the IBD 50 . Alphabet (GOOGL) rose 2% in above-average volume, nearing an all-time high. It's in a follow-on buy area from support at the 50-day line.
LinkedIn (LNKD) gained 3% as it continues to work on the handle of a cup base with a buy point at 258.49. Facebook (FB) advanced 2% as it shapes a flat base with a 110.75 entry.
In other economic news, housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, but the Purchasing Managers' index and U.S. industrial production fell below expectations.
Weekly jobless claims and the Philly Fed business outlook survey for December are on tap for Thursday.

Stocks stuck close to home in early afternoon trade Wednesday, an hour before the Federal Reserve was to announce its decision on interest rates.

All three major indexes ran to a peak within the first hour of trade, then began easing back slowly in weak trade. By 1 p.m. the S&P 500 was sticking to a 0.4% gain. The Nasdaq was up 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average hung on to a 0.2% advance.

Early economic data showed a surprise surge in November housing-start and building permit activity. Manufacturing news was disappointing, with a preliminary Purchasing Managers' Index estimate from researcher Markit and factory output and capacity numbers from the Federal Reserve all below consensus expectations.
Still, the market was primarily tuned to the Fed channel, where a policy decision was scheduled to be announced at 2 p.m. ET, followed by a press conference with Fed Chair Janet Yellen at 2:30.
Oil-related stocks were surprisingly resilient, given diving oil prices that sent West Texas Intermediate down 4%, to below $36 a barrel, and Brent crude 3% lower to just above $37.

Oil groups were only four of the 10 worst declines at midday among 197 industries tracked by IBD. The group may be seeing some benefit from a rider to the spending bill working its way through Congress which would lift the 40-year ban on U.S. oil exports.

Solar electrical components and systems makers soared, also due to provisions tied to Congress' spending package which would extend solar subsidies for consumers and businesses. SolarCity (SCTY) spiked 27%. Sunedison (SUNE) bolted 18% higher. First Solar (FSLR) spiked 8%.

On the IBD 50 list, Tesoro (TSO) kept its 3% gain to lead the group. Refiners would be net losers if the export ban were lifted, but yet another provision to the proffered spending plan would provide tax perks to offset the impact. Tesoro's light-volume gain left it 3% below its 50-day moving average, and less than 0.5% below a 105.64 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. The stock's pullback undercut that buy point by 7%.

Mortgage origination servicer Ellie Mae (ELLI) popped nearly 3%, possibly buoyed by the strong showing in November housing starts. The stock's second straight gain off Monday's low left it still 5% below its converged 50- and 200-day moving averages.

Stocks plunged further Friday to cap a week filled with big swings in both directions. The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 2.1%, the S&P 500 shed 1.8% and the Nasdaq gave up 1.6%, breaching its 200-day moving average. According to early figures, volume swelled across the board, partly due to options expiration.Thursday's and Friday's sell-offs negated big gains Wednesday after the Fed rate hike, leaving the indexes down for the week.Oil drillers, transport and retail stocks were among the biggest losers in the stock market today. All but one Dow stock, Caterpillar (CAT), closed lower. Boeing (BA) was the biggest decliner, down more than 4%, after Wells Fargo cut the jet maker's rating to market perform from outperform.Apple (AAPL) also weighed, sliding 3% in fast turnover to a near four-month low. Disney (DIS) fell nearly 4% as BTIG downgraded the stock to sell amid concerns that weak results in the entertainment giant's cable business will offset strong profits from Star Wars.Package delivery providers UPS (UPS) and FedEx (FDX) fell 2% and 3%, respectively, on reports that Amazon.com (AMZN) is in talks to lease jets to start its own overnight delivery service, according to the Seattle Times. Both stocks are trading below their 50-day and 200-day moving average lines.Gold miners, solar and steel stocks led the scant upside. Solar issues have advanced for six straight sessions. On Friday, Congress approved an extension of the solar investment tax credit through 2024. The solar group soared 16% Wednesday, ahead of the vote.SolarEdge Technologies (SEDG) gained 3% in brisk trade. The new issue is up 48% from its 18 offering price but 37% off its June high. FBR Capital began covering the Israeli company with an outperform rating.Decliners trumped advancers on theIBD 50 . Online mortgage services provider Ellie Mae (ELLI) and Argentine bank holding company Grupo Financiero Galicia (GGAL) fell 8% and 6%, respectively.But software maker Red Hat (RHT) rose 3% in heavy volume. It cleared an 83.10 flat-base buy point intraday but closed below the entry. The software maker reported fiscal Q3 results that topped views and offered mixed guidance.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo and on Facebook.

Online shoppers love Mondays. According to an Adobe Systems (ADBE) survey, three of the four biggest shopping days of the year will be on Mondays. Adobe estimates online shoppers spent $1.92 billion on Monday, Dec. 7, and projects they'll spend $1.95 billion next Monday, Dec. 14. The European Commission reportedly will announce a formal investigation of McDonald's tax deals with Luxembourg as early as Thursday, according to sources cited by the Wall Street Journal McDonald's offices in France were inspected in 2013. Cyber cash registers continued to ring late this week, as shoppers seemed to wait later this season than in past years to wrap up holiday shopping. The so-called Amazon.com (AMZN) effect — its Prime loyalty program includes free two-day shipping and relatively low-cost one-day or same-day shipping, which shoppers have come to expect in general — contributed to a U-shaped…

Flying drones drop Chipotle (CMG) burritos, 7-Eleven Slurpees and Amazon.com (AMZN) sundries on doorsteps while robots scoot down sidewalks to deliver Domino's (DPZ) pizzas and other meals to homes.These images might conjure thoughts that we've finally entered the age of mechanical gofers, or that we'll soon farm out a slew of summer jobs to robots. But hold on to your transformers for a bit.While companies such as Amazon are pushing the idea of delivery bots — the e-commerce giant now says it wants to start using them for commercial deliveries by the end of 2017 — widespread use of robotic couriers could be years away.Consumers in a few regions and limited test markets are the only ones seeing the benefits, and possible drawbacks, of machines that carry food, drinks and everyday goods to their door. And the tests are raising more questions than they're answering.For one, are these deliveries just publicity stunts designed to show consumer brands are on the cutting edge of technology? Or do they show a future where it might be practical for robots to routinely make home deliveries?"Is there a legitimate business model here? Is there a real need for this? Can I measure ROI (return on investment)? Those are the questions that need to be answered," ABI Research analyst Dan Kara told Investor's Business Daily.It's not clear right now that a robot can handle deliveries as fast or better than a human. Further, the long-term costs of developing and deploying bot couriers is unclear. Plus, companies have yet to figure out how to protect that mechanical merchandise.In other words, it could be some time before you'll see robot-delivered pizza on a grand scale. For now, delivery bots are very much an experiment, with companies and consumers in a dot-com-esque honeymoon phase. Some companies are dreaming big, and harsh reality has yet to set in.Amazon got the public excited about the idea of aerial delivery drones when it announced its Prime Air initiative in December 2013. It wasn't until this past March that it conducted its first drone delivery in the U.S., transporting a bottle of sunscreen to a resort in Palm Springs, Calif., during a tech conference.Still, Amazon is sticking to its vision, and hopes to deliver small packages of up to 5 pounds in 30 minutes or less by drones that can fly up to 50 miles per hour.Retail behemoth Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) has expressed interest in making drone deliveries as has Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL). Google has a drone delivery initiative called Project Wing that is looking to develop automated aircraft to deliver everything from consumer goods to emergency medicine. Last September, Project Wing conducted a test on the Virginia Tech campus, delivering Chipotle burritos by air to students and employees.The movement has prompted delivery specialists, such as FedEx (FDX) and United Parcel Service (UPS), to evaluate their options. Self-driving trucks eventually are expected to deploy small robots to deliver packages to your door. But aerial drones are considered a better solution for greater distances, especially in rural and hard-to-reach places.Gartner analyst Gerald Van Hoy believes that commercial drone deliveries in the U.S. are a few years away, but within sight. Business-to-business drone deliveries might help pave the way for consumer deliveries, Van Hoy told IBD. It is easy to calculate the payback of sending a drone to deliver a tool to a worker in the field vs. sending a human driver, he said.By the same token, business uses of wheeled delivery robots could lead to consumer applications as the technology improves and the value proposition becomes clear, ABI's Kara said.Venture capital firms and corporations are funding robotic delivery initiatives on the chance that they could become a huge deal. But that might not happen, Kara said, noting that many millions of dollars were invested in corporate telepresence robots — sort of interoffice gofers — before that market fizzled.Analysts point out robotic delivery systems could help restaurants that struggle to find enough delivery workers. They also could be a hedge against rising employee costs, especially with the Fight For $15 political movement to raise the minimum wage.Ultimately, there will be questions on regulatory restrictions and finding the right business model. Tech companies and government regulators are working out how best to allow delivery robots in the public air space and on streets and walkways. The biggest questions are business-related, and whether delivery bots are economically feasible, Kara said.A raft of companies have developed robotics, including Google, Northrop Grumman (NOC) and Roomba maker iRobot (IRBT). A few private companies, however, have come to the forefront when it comes to delivery bots.They include two startups, Marble and Starship Technologies, two private robotic firms. In April, Yelp's (YELP) Eat24 food delivery service partnered with Marble to test robotic deliveries with a handful of restaurants in a couple San Francisco neighborhoods.The Eat24-branded robots are the size of a shopping cart. They navigate city sidewalks with artificial intelligence, cameras, ultrasonic sensors and light detection, or lidar, sensors. Typical deliveries are within a mile. Customers are sent a four-digit code to open the four-wheeled robot's storage compartment.Rival delivery robot firm Starship started making food deliveries in Silicon Valley in March. Starship also has conducted trials in Austin, Texas; Portland, Ore.; and Washington, D.C., as well as a dozen European countries.Starship robots are roughly the size of large picnic coolers and have six wheels. In March, Starship announced a deal with Domino's to deliver pizzas by robot within a one-mile radius around its outlets in select German and Dutch cities.While sidewalk robots are seen as the best solution for short-distance deliveries in cities, some politicians don't like the idea.In May, San Francisco Supervisor Norman Yee introduced legislation that would ban autonomous delivery robots from city sidewalks, largely for safety concerns. Those concerns range from machines getting in the way of cars and pedestrians to lawbreakers stealing or vandalizing them.On the other side of the coin, humanitarian concerns are a consideration.Last September, UPS partnered with drone maker CyPhy Works to test the use of drones to make commercial deliveries of packages to remote locations. The companies staged a mock delivery of urgently needed medicine from Beverly, Mass., to Children's Island, about three miles off the Atlantic coast. In the mock scenario, the drone successfully carried an asthma inhaler to a child at a camp on the island.Zipline International is using fixed-wing drones to deliver medical products, such as blood products and rabies treatments, to remote locations. It currently is serving 21 hospitals in Rwanda. Its drones can deliver to any site within about 47 miles, or 93 miles round-trip. As of November, Zipline had raised $43 million in funding."The humanitarian side of drone deliveries is starting to be talked about a lot more," Gretchen West, co-executive director of the Commercial Drone Alliance, told IBD. "It's delivering medicine, aid and supplies after a catastrophe or to remote locations where roads could be washed out. We're starting to see a lot more of that, not just consumer delivery."Already, several companies are making headway deploying robots to deliver items in structured environments like hospitals and hotels, he said. Pittsburgh-based Aethon makes delivery robots for hospitals to ferry food, medicine, towels and other items. San Jose, Calif.-based Savioke makes robots for delivering items to consumers in hotels and high-rise buildings.West says drone deliveries to consumers will happen, but will take longer for the puzzle pieces to come together. Right now, commercial drones in the U.S. face strict limitations.For instance, they can't fly over people, must be operated within visual line of sight, and can't fly at night. Many of these problems will be solved by an unmanned aircraft system traffic management system under development by NASA, she said."It will take several years," West said. "None of this moves very quickly."

X Stocks closed higher Friday, launching June with a two-session run-up that left the Nasdaq, Dow industrials and S&P 500 at record closing highs.The Nasdaq scored a runaway win, up 0.9%, as the S&P 500 climbed 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average took a 0.3% gain. Small caps also showed some hustle, with Russell 2000 futures bagging a nearly 0.7% advance.Preliminary data showed volume was weaker than on Thursday, across both the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchanges.Before the open, the Labor Department reported weaker-than-expected jobs growth in May which, along with another session of weak oil prices, led to Friday's dicey first hour of trade. But a decrease in the unemployment rate — to a 16-year low — provided a positive headline number to bolster confidence and drive stocks to midafternoon highs before drifting into the close.For the week, the Nasdaq climbed 1.5%, its sixth gain in the past seven weeks. The S&P 500 added 0.9% and the Dow tacked on a 0.6% advance.Makers of RVs and mobile homes posted the day's best gain among industries, as Winnebago Industries (WGO), Skyline (SKY) and Cavco Industries (CVCO) all surged. Winnebago led, up more than 4%. Industry leader Thor Industries (THO) rose 1%, ahead of its fiscal third-quarter report scheduled for after the close on Monday.Oil prices tumbled 4% in a second straight weekly decline, putting a damper on energy sector trading. Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) were the loss leaders on the Dow, each down more than 1.1%.  Oil and coal groups posted seven of the 10-worst losses on Friday, and for the week, among the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD.Microsoft (MSFT) led the Dow, rising more than 2% to a new high, leaving it extended after a May rebound from 10-week support.FedEx (FDX) cracked a 2.3% gain in strong trade, breaking out but remaining in buy range above a flat-base buy point of 201.67. Volume finished more than 60% above its 50-day average, a good sign of solid institutional demand.IBD Global Leader Broadcom (AVGO) scrambled up 9% in powerful trade after reporting  healthy fiscal second-quarter sales late Thursday that beat expectations. The gain sent the stock out of buy range above a 227.85 buy point in a flat base.TTM Technologies (TTMI) led the IBD 50 list, jumping 3.5% in quiet trade as it works on a four-month flat base with a 17.96 buy point.Slated for release on Monday: first-quarter productivity and labor-cost numbers, April factory orders and May estimates from services purchasing managers. Purchasing mangers indexes are due out Sunday night in China and Japan.RELATED:Politics May Upstage Apple's Big Show: Investing Action PlanAs The OPEC/Shale Oil Wars Rage, Consumers Chalk Up A Rare Win

Biotechs and software led a solid Nasdaq advance, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index hit record highs. Boeing (BA) announced a slew of Paris Air Show orders, while oil prices kept falling. The Fed cleared big banks in their annual stress tests while China cracked down on Weibo (WB). Amazon (AMZN) spooked more retailers.X The Nasdaq rose 1.8% for the week as biotechs and other medicals soared on eased fears about price controls and also in reaction to the Senate GOP health bill. Celgene (CELG) was among the biotech breakouts, while Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) soared out of buy range. Desktop software also was a big winner, with Oracle (ORCL) breaking out on earnings. Amazon fears intensified for apparel and sporting goods stories. The Dow industrials and S&P 500 index hit record highs Monday, but pared gains amid weakness in oil and retail stocks. The Dow finished fractionally higher while the S&P 500  rose 0.2%.Biotech stocks surged 10% this week as concerns that President Trump will tamp down on drug prices began to subside. Big winners in the rally included Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Celgene (CELG), which popped 12.5% and nearly 10%, respectively. Clovis Oncology (CLVS) spiked58% after strong trial data suggested a much-wider use for its ovarian cancer drug. Analysts called for "growth" stocks to gain the most and one sees the rally continuing another 15%.Traditional drug giants also fared well, with Novartis (NVS) breaking out to a buy point and Merck (MRK) nearing an entry.Boeing (BA) beat out Airbus (EADSY) on commercial jet orders at the 2017 Paris Air Show, an event typically won by the European aerospace giant. Boeing said it had "incremental orders and commitments" of 571 airplanes, valued at $74.8 billion at list prices. But analysts said "a staggering 64%" of Boeing's orders at the show weren't firm. Airbus said it booked firm orders of 144 planes valued at $18.5 billion and memorandums of understanding for 182 aircraft valued at $21.2 billion. Analysts weren't expecting many deals in Paris, but orders were double the $50 billion seen at last year's show in Farnborough, England. Boeing shares rose about 3% for the week, hitting new highs. Airbus set a record high Monday, but pared its weekly gain to 0.9%.RELATED: Why Boeing's Paris Air Show Orders Are 'Staggering''Hybrid' Design For New Boeing Midrange Jet Could Hit This Sweet SpotWhy Lockheed May Move F-16 Production To India From TexasOracle (ORCL) earnings easily topped views while revenue advanced 3% as the software giant's overall cloud revenue shot up 64% vs. a year earlier. Oracle had been a latecomer to the on-demand, cloud software shift but the transition is in full force now. Shares surged 13%, breaking out to a record high. Meanwhile, two other Software-Database leaders soared to record highs on stronger-than-expected earnings. Adobe Systems (ADBE) raised Q3 guidance after reporting a 44% EPS gain for its fiscal Q2. Red Hat (RHT) EPS climbed 12% in its fiscal Q1 while revenue rose 19%. The open-source Linux software provider also gave bullish current-quarter guidance. Adobe rose 5.5% while Red Hat climbed 13.2%.Crude oil prices fell to 10-month lows during the week amid continued oversupply concerns. Weekly U.S. crude stockpiles fell 2.45 million barrels, the Energy Information Administration said, double what was expected. But domestic crude production nudged up to 9.35 million barrels per day. Meanwhile, Libyan oil production rose sharply after a dispute ended with a German oil company. Exports from Nigeria are expected to hit 226,000 BPD in August vs. 164,000 BPD in July, according to Reuters. Saudi Arabia's Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman was appointed as heir to the kingdom's throne and is widely expected to continue current oil policies. He was a major force behind Riyadh's Saudi Vision 2030 reform initiative aimed at curbing the country's reliance on crude.RELATED:Oil Reverses Sharply Lower On Supply FearsJPMorgan (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and the nation's biggest global banks would have enough capital to continue lending in an economic meltdown, the first round of the Federal Reserve's annual stress-results showed. None of the 34 banks tested had key capital levels below the minimum set by the Fed. But bank stocks generally edged lower Friday. Wall Street's attention will turn to results from the second portion of the exam that comes out on Wednesday. That portion will determine what the banks can give in buybacks and dividends and ultimately whether the firms pass or fail the tests on quantitative and qualitative grounds.JPMorgan, BofA, Goldman, Citi, Wells Fargo Pass Fed's Stress TestChina ordered Weibo (WB) and two other online platforms to shut down audiovisual streaming, presumably for user content that violated the country's political standards. Weibo tumbled 6.1% on Thursday, with majority-owner Sina Corp. (SINA), lost 4.8%. Alibaba (BABA), which owns a big minority stake in the Twitter (TWTR)-like Weibo, edged lower. Momo (MOMO) and YY (YY), two social media firms with a lot of streaming video, sold off initially but Momo closed up and YY pared losses. Sina, Momo and YY are all IBD 50 stocks.RELATED:Weibo Crackdown Spurs Selling, But Not Panic, In China InternetsAmazon struck fear in more retail groups, slamming many apparel and sporting goods chains. The e-commerce giant announced Amazon Prime Wardrobe, a home try-on system that lets users have three or more items shipped to them for free to try on at home, then be charged for what they keep. That hit Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN), TJX (TJX) and more. Meanwhile, Bloomberg sources said Nike (NKE) would sell footwear directly on Amazon via a brand-registry program, sending shares of already-reeling Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), Foot Locker (FL) and others sharply lower. But Finish Line (FINL) rebounded Friday despite mixed quarterly results.Meanwhile, Whole Foods Market (WFM) pushed a little further beyond the 42-a-share takeover price from Amazon, leading some to wonder if another bidder could be ready to emerge with an even bigger offer than $13.7 billion. Barclays said it "would not be surprised is there is a bidding war," and JPMorgan analysts have pegged Wal-Mart (WMT) as a possible contender. But Reuters reported late Friday that Wal-Mart is not planning a Whole Foods bid. Whole Foods closed the week up 0.6% at 42.94 after hitting 43.84 Friday afternoon.RELATED:Here's The Latest Group Having An Amazon-Induced Anxiety AttackPrime Wardrobe: Is This How Amazon Kills Macy's In Fashion Game?Uber Technologies founder Travis Kalanick resigned as chief executive officer following a shareholder revolt. The ride-hailing company had been exposed as having a workplace culture that included sexual harassment and discrimination. Uber also has been losing U.S. market share to Lyft.Twitter (TWTR) stock rose 11% as a bullish research report said the struggling company has improved its video strategy and execution. The report came on the same day Twitter announced a way for people to earn money by streaming live on its Periscope video service. Snapchat-operator Snap (SNAP) was under increased pressure from the Instagram Stories feature by Facebook (FB), which has grown to 250 million users, vs. 166 million for Snapchat. Snap is trading close to its IPO price of 17.Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) surged nearly 24% for the week as it launched its latest server processors for data centers. AMD's new Epyc server chips will compete with processors from industry leader Intel (INTC). Joining AMD at a launch event in Austin, Texas, were customers and partners backing Epyc, including Microsoft (MSFT) Azure, Baidu (BIDU), Dell Technologies (DVMT) and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE). Intel shares fell to a 2017 low.Shares of FedEx (FDX) rose 2.3% for the week, hitting a record high and moving out of buy range as the package delivery giant easily topped expectations for its fiscal fourth quarter Tuesday, shaking of EPS misses in the last two quarters. Earnings climbed 29% on a 21% jump in revenue to $15.7 billion. Investments to modernize its aircraft fleet and expand ground operations paid off, FedEx, while guiding full-year profit high. Rival UPS announced Monday that it will charge retailers an extra fee for holiday deliveries, while FedEx said it would consider that. Both shipping giants could be challenged as key customer Amazon (AMZN) expands its own delivery services.RELATED:FedEx Easily Tops Q4 Earnings, Revenue Forecasts; Guides Profit HighStrong SUV and truck sales helped to drive an across-the-board beat Wednesday for used-car superstore CarMax (KMX). First-quarter EPS climbed almost 26% year over year to $1.13 on a 10.1% rise in revenue to $4.54 billion. Total unit sales of used vehicles  jumped 14.1%. But even with large and medium SUVs and trucks accounting for a bigger share of the mix, the average used vehicle price fell 1.9% vs. a year earlier, accelerating from a 1.6% drop in the prior quarter. A flood of off-lease cars is hitting pricing, one reason while new-car sales are slumping. CarMax rose 1.7% in an up-and-down week.MSCI (MSCI) on Tuesday finally greenlighted the inclusion of mainland China stocks in its key emerging markets index. Wall Street had been closely watching the decision, since several funds — including the $32 billion iShares Emerging Markets ETF (EEM) — track or are benchmarked to that index. China's weight in the benchmark will jump to upward of 40% from the current 26%. The move surprised the markets; MSCI had given a red light to mainland stocks or "A shares" on three previous tries.EQT Corp. (EQT) agreed to buy Rice Energy (RICE) for around $6.7 billion. The deal, set to close in Q4, would create the U.S.' largest natural-gas producer and strengthen EQT's position in the Marcellus and Utica shale regions.Accenture (ACN) reported in-line fiscal Q3 profit and reported top-line growth slightly above views as new digital, cloud and security products and services reached 50% of revenue but management commentary on weakness in the health care market sent shares down.

Dow Jones industrial average component Wal-Mart (WMT) has begun offering discounts to online shoppers who pick up their orders, leveraging the discount giant's thousands of physical stores, something Amazon (AMZN) lacks. But the price cuts are light, unless the items are heavy.Wal-Mart aims to reduce shipping costs and pass those savings onto customers. The "last mile" of shipping goods to customers is very expensive for traditional retailers, while Amazon gets bigger discounts from UPS (UPS) and FedEx (FDX) due to its massive shipping volumes.Wal-Mart is offering varying discounts on some 10,000 items to start, with plans to expand that to 1 million. (The discounts are not available in Alaska and Hawaii.)It's using technology developed by Jet.com, sold to Wal-Mart last year for $3.3 billion. Heavy but inexpensive items will get bigger price cuts.And that's what's clear from walmart.com.Discounts are slim for electronics.But if you're willing to load up heavy or bulky goods in and out of your car, there are bigger incentives.Wal-Mart shares rose 0.2% to 74.07 in the stock market today, hitting an eight-month high intraday. The stock is in range from a 72.90 buy point. Amazon edged down 0.5% to 899.20, just in range from an 860.96 follow-on entry.UPS rose 0.35% intraday while FedEx dipped 3 cents. Both stocks tumbled last week on news of Wal-Mart's in-store discount plans on concerns that will reduce shipping volumes just as they invest heavily for increased e-commerce activity.RELATED:Wal-Mart Will Pay You To Pick Up Your Online Orders; Your Move, AmazonRetail And E-Commerce News And Stocks To WatchWal-Mart's 4th E-Commerce Deal In 4 Months May Cost $300 Million

UPS (UPS) announced plans Monday to ramp up its Saturday activity as FedEx (FDX) invests in more ground operations to deal with growing e-commerce shipments from Amazon (AMZN) and others.UPS said it will expand Saturday ground pickups and delivery to New York, Chicago, Boston and 12 other metro areas this month, after testing the service in Atlanta, Philadelphia and Los Angeles last year, and has plans to expand the service to 4,700 U.S. cities by the holiday season.The increased activity will create 6,000 jobs once the plan is fully implemented in 2018, but UPS said it won't be investing more in buildings or vehicles.UPS shares slid 0.8% to 106.40 on the stock market today. FedEx shares rose 0.1% to 195.36.IBD'S TAKE: E-commerce is soaring, but don't count out brick and mortar stores at malls just yet.Amazon and e-commerce has fueled UPS and FedEx revenue for years, but the volume and need for ever-faster delivery has strained the shipping giants, especially around the holidays.FedEx reported a surprise earnings decline on March 21, its first in four years. But FedEx was upbeat that heavy investments will pay off. FedEx shares have been up and down and up following its Q3 results.UPS said e-commerce was a major factor in its decision to ramp up Saturday shipping, saying in a press release that: "Online retailers stand to benefit from fewer lost sales due to abandoned online shopping carts, enhanced ship-from-store options and fewer items being out of stock."Amazon and the increase of two day shipping with its Prime membership has helped UPS and FedEx volumes but the e-commerce giant is expanding its own shipping operations and has plans to use drones for smaller-package, same-day deliveries.Amazon shares edged up 0.6% to 891.51 after hitting a fresh all-time high of 892.76 earlier.RELATED:FedEx Delivers Two Surprises Late: Earnings And Stock Reaction

X Wal-Mart (WMT) next week will begin offering price discounts for 10,000 goods picked up at a store location, expanding to one million items by the end of June. It's the latest evidence that the Dow Jones industrial average component is driving e-commerce innovation under new online chief Marc Lore, leveraging its brick-and-mortar locations vs. Amazon.com (AMZN).Wal-Mart will offer varying discounts, using technology developed by Jet.com, which Lore sold to Wal-Mart last year for $3.3 billion. Heavy but inexpensive items will get bigger price cuts.Online shipping costs, especially the "last mile" of delivery to customers, are incredibly expensive. Wal-Mart and other traditional retailers have encouraged in-store pickup, waiving shipping fees. But many customers have preferred to wait for online delivery, with Amazon investing heavily to speed up deliveries and giving Amazon Prime members free two-day shipping. Amazon, with its massive size, gets huge discounts from UPS (UPS) and FedEx (FDX) over even large brick-and-mortar retailers.Now Wal-Mart is giving shoppers a clear incentive to make in-store pickups, turning their brick-and-mortar locations into a virtue.Amazon isn't oblivious to the multichannel threat. It's opened a handful of physical bookstores. It's also testing a grocery store in Seattle that features automated checkout.Amazon reportedly mulled buying Whole Foods Stores (WFM) last year, Bloomberg reported.Wal-Mart shares rose 1 cent to 73.44 in the stock market today. On Tuesday, Wal-Mart rose 0.5% to 73.43, in range from a 72.90 buy point taken on Friday.Amazon slid 0.7% to 896.23 after dipping 0.5% to 902.36 on Tuesday. Amazon is still in range from an 860.96 four-weeks-tight buy point.Wal-Mart's holiday quarter U.S. online sales surged 29%, but the retailer has been even more aggressive in 2017.Earlier this year, Wal-Mart dropped its ShippingPass subscription alternative to Amazon Prime, announcing free two-day shipping for online orders of at $35 or more. Amazon, which had raised its non-Prime free-shipping threshold to $50, brought that back to $35, but with a longer delivery span.Walmart.com shoppers can now set a pickup time to have their groceries loaded into the cars, helping to explain why Amazon is testing its own grocery stores and considering a Whole Foods takeover.Wal-Mart also has continued to make online acquisitions, including niche retailers ModCloth, Moosejaw and Shoebuy. It's also opened an online innovation center.Wal-Mart's in-store pickup discounts could show a path for Target (TGT), Macy's (M) and other traditional retailers to make an omnichannel strategy work. But it's also a threat. Target and others seeking to turn physical locations into giant online lockers may find they have to pass on the shipping savings to customers.Target and many other retailers already are being squeezed by Wal-Mart's renewed push to lower prices generally.Wal-Mart has been a reliable dividend stock, having raised the payout every year since 1974. The company just raised the quarterly payment to 51 cents a share. The annualized dividend yield is nearly 3%.

XParcel-delivery service FedEx (FDX) reported fiscal third-quarter earnings unexpectedly fell vs. a year earlier for the time in four years.Estimates: Earnings per share of $2.62, up 4%. That would be its fourth straight quarter of decelerating EPS growth and the smallest gain in three years. Revenue should climb 18% to $14.986 billion. The quarter began on Dec. 1, which means it includes much of FedEx's increasingly frantic holiday shopping season.Results: Adjusted EPS of $2.35, down 6%. Revenue rose 18% to $15 billion.Outlook: FedEx sees full-year EPS of $10.80-$11.30 excluding pension accounting adjustments. It's not clear if that figure compares to the consensus for $12 but if so would suggests a big Q4 miss, even accounting for Q3's shortfall.Stock: Shares fell 4% in initial after-hours trading, but then rebounded to trade up 2% to 195.71.FedEx closed down 0.2% to 191.85, giving up intraday gains shortly before the close amid a heavy overall sell-off in the stock market today. The stock has held onto its 50-day line, trading tightly in recent days, and is making its way through a flat base with a potential buy point of 201.67.FedEx's operating profit margin was 7.5%, down from 9.2% a year earlier. Operating margin for its Ground segment slid to 11% from a year-earlier 12.6%.Analysts in recent months have zeroed in on FedEx's margins, particularly in its ground delivery segment, as more customers shop online at Amazon.com (AMZN) and others, and come to expect prompt — and more frequent — delivery.FedEx has poured money into automating its delivery infrastructure to hasten the flow of packages through delivery hubs to their destinations. Those efforts could dent margins short-term but cut costs and help profits further out."We are confident our strategic investments to expand our global scope and portfolio of solutions position FedEx for greater long-term profitable growth as we adapt to meet the evolving needs of our customers," said FedEx CEO Fred Smith.However, Barclays said Monday that margins in FedEx's Ground segment "are likely near a trough." Cowen said margins "likely bottomed" in the second quarter of the company's fiscal year, but that the strain would likely continue.Cowen analyst Helane Becker also expressed concern about how well FedEx did over the holidays."Several customers overpromised and underdelivered in the peak shipping season and this resulted in lower volumes at FedEx," she wrote in a research note dated Friday. "We believe this will result in muted volume growth in the Ground segment."FedEx and rival UPS (UPS) also face a potential challenge from the ever-embattled U.S. Postal Service, which has more than doubled its "competitive" — that is, cheaper — package volumes since 2012, Barclays said recently."Pricing has clearly been under pressure from the USPS ... which likely negatively impacted results for FedEx and UPS," Barclays analyst Brandon Oglenski wrote in a research note on Monday.Amazon also has begun its own shipping, taking a piece of business that traditionally went to FedEx and UPS.However, FedEx's international prospects remain solid, and Oglenski said "global trade expansion in 2017 is shaping up to be the strongest witnessed this cycle, signaling supply chain tightness and a potential for shippers to 'trade up' for premium services."UPS closed down 0.6%, trading below its 50- and 200-day moving averages. UPS rose slightly late after initially edging lower.Amazon hit an all-time high in morning trade but reversed to slide 1.6% as the major market averages skidded.RELATED:UPS Dives On Q4 Miss, Outlook; Amazon Plans Kentucky Air HubFedEx Q2 Earnings Miss As Margins Shrink; Shares Drop Late

The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite suffered their worst one-day loss of the year amid concerns that tax cuts could be derailed. Apple (AAPL) released new gear. Nike (NKE) sales and guidance disappointed. Sears Holdings (SHLD) said it has "substantial concerns" about staying in business, while the auto sector tumbled on Ford (F) earnings guidance and other news.The Dow industrials, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq all gave up 1% or more, with Tuesday's losses being their worst performance in several months for all three major averages. The GOP health care bill was pulled from a vote Friday afternoon for lack of support. The bill's woes had raised that President Trump's agenda of tax cuts, deregulation and infrastructure — which have fueled the stock market since Election Day — may also falter. House Speaker Paul Ryan signaled a quick shift to tax reform though. Bank stocks broke support, extending losses following the Federal Reserve meeting, as Treasury yields also moved lower.Nike (NKE) tumbled on weak sales and gross margins and cautious comments about retail conditions. Sears said it may struggle to remain a "going concern" as brick-and-mortar stores go from bad to worse. Automakers, lenders and rental car agencies fell on declining used-car prices and a profit warning from Ford.Fiber-optic stocks were big winners amid a key LA conference. Micron Technology (MU) jumped on strong quarterly earnings and guidance. FedEx (FDX) reported a surprise earnings drop but predicted an "excellent" current quarter.Nike beat big on earnings, largely due to lower SG&A costs. But revenue growth of 5% fell short of views and marked the lightest gain in five quarters. Gross margin shrank more than projected. The report contrasted with strong Adidas (ADDYY) results just a few weeks earlier. Nike management uncharacteristically commented on the unsteadiness of the current retail landscape. Shares fell 7% on Wednesday, but recouped much of those losses on Thursday-Friday, retaking their 50-day and 200-day lines.RELATED:Sears (SHLD) indicated that "substantial doubt exists" over its ability to keep operating, following years of losing billions and competition from e-commerce and discount chains. Women's apparel chain Bebe (BEBE) was also reportedly considering closing all its stores to become an online-only retailer, while Payless could reportedly soon file for bankruptcy. Shares of Sears and Bebe crashed.RELATED:Consumer electronics giant Apple (AAPL) rejiggered its smartphone lineup, launching a red iPhone 7 and doubling the data storage in its entry-level iPhone SE. It also upgraded its standard 9.7-inch iPad and slashed the starting price 17.5% to $329. The moves came ahead of rival Samsung's March 29 product launch event when it is expected to release its Galaxy S8 smartphone. Apple also bulked up its iOS apps, debuting a video creation app called Clips and buying the task automation app called Workflow.RELATED:Ford Motor (F) sees Q1 EPS well below analyst forecasts, citing higher costs and weaker demand. The follows a wave of reports warning about falling used-car prices, which could hit new car values and demand as well as impact auto lending that has propped up sales. Ford fell 6.9% for the week after undercutting its 50-day line on March 17. General Motors (GM) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) also skidded lower. Ally Financial (ALLY), which issued its own warning, citing used-car prices, lost 5.6%, while car rental giant Avis (CAR) tumbled 12.9%.RELATED:Existing-home sales fell 3.7% to annual rate of 5.48 million in February, less than expected, after hitting a 10-year high in January. Supply of homes on the market fell vs. a year earlier, pushing up prices. That's good news for new-home sales, which jumped to their second-best reading of the expansion. Median new-home prices fell though.Meanwhile, homebuilders Lennar (LEN) and KB Home (KBH) reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue. But homebuilder shares retreated somewhat following the prior week's post-Fed gains.RELATED:FedEx (FDX) fiscal third-quarter earnings unexpectedly fell amid heavy investments. Revenue growth was in line. But the parcel deliverer holds an "expectation of an excellent fourth quarter" marked by stronger margins in its Ground segment. In that segment, the company has spent big on its delivery systems to handle a swell of online orders. FedEx rose 2.1% on Wednesday, but fell 3.4% on Thursday and extended losses Friday, closing below its 50-day line for the first time in weeks.RELATED:Chinese internet giant Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) reported fourth-quarter earnings that jumped 47% vs. a year earlier, but missed Wall Street estimates. Revenue surged 44% to 43.9 billion yuan, or $6.37 billion, slightly above views for 44.25 billion yuan. But costs leapt 60% to 20.2 billion yuan as Tencent spends heavily on its WeChat super-app.RELATED:Esperion Therapeutics (ESPR) stock soared 74% Monday after outlining its path to winning approval for its cholesterol fighter, bempedoic acid, approved to lower "bad" LDL cholesterol and as an adjunct to statin therapy. The FDA said an ongoing phase three trial in patients with elevated cholesterol levels would be sufficient for approval. The March 20 stock spike followed a 20% tumble on March 17 on a disappointing trial of a rivaling drug from Amgen (AMGN). Though Amgen's drug Repatha didn't reduce the risk of cardiovascular death, it did cut down on stroke, heart attack and coronary revascularization.Shares of The Medicines Co. (MDCO) also got a jump-start Monday after it and partner Alnylam Pharmaceuticals (ALNY) reported strong results for cholesterol-drug, Inclisiran, in a midstage trial.RELATED:U.S. crude futures fell 1.7% to $47.97 a barrel for the week as shale gains continued. U.S. crude stockpiles rose by 4.954 million barrels in the latest week, the Energy Information Administration said, vs. the 2.8 million barrel build analysts expected. U.S. crude production rose 0.2% to 9.129 million barrels, the highest since February 2016. Meanwhile, Marathon Oil (MRO) said it would buy 21,000 net acres in the Permian's Northern Delaware basin for $700 million, following its 70,000 net acre buy earlier this month. Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) have recently announced deals to expand their holdings in the low-cost Texas play.RELATED:For the fiscal second quarter ended Feb. 28, Accenture (ACN) earned $1.33 per share, down a penny vs. a year earlier. Revenue climbed 4.7% to $8.32 billion, the third straight quarter of gradually decelerating growth and just below views. The global tech consulting and services company expects fiscal Q3 revenue in line, lifting its full-year revenue and EPS guidance slightly. But shares, which broke out to an all-time high on Wednesday ahead of results, tumbled on Thursday and Friday, moving below their 50-day line.The administrator of health savings accounts gave mixed guidance amid political uncertainty over the GOP's health revamp, which would boost HSAs. HealthEquity (HQY) sees full-year EPS of 50-55 cents, below consensus for 56 cents, on revenue of $220 million-$225 million, with the midpoint above consensus for $221.6 million. In Q4, EPS rose 40% to 7 cents, topping forecasts by 3 cents, as revenue climbed 30% to $46.8 million, above estimates for $45.6 million. HSA membership grew 28% from a year ago to 2.7 million. Shares fell 12.5% for the week.RELATED:

XFutures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq 100 pointed modestly higher Tuesday morning, with a four pack of Federal Reserve regional presidents on tap.Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.1% vs. fair value. The S&P 500 climbed about 0.2% above fair value. The Nasdaq 100 was up 0.3%.On Monday, the Dow industrials fell a fraction while the S&P 500 index edged down 0.2%, the third straight losses for both averages. The Nasdaq composite hit an all-time high for a second straight session, but for a third straight day ended with a gain of less than 1 point.New York Fed President William Dudley speaks at 6:35 a.m. ET in London. Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren will speak at a closed-door meeting in Bali, Indonesia. Kansas City Fed President Esther George addresses the economy at noon while Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester will speak on the Fed's outlook and communications at 6 p.m. ET.The Fed raised interest rates last week and signaled that it was sticking to its plan for just two more hikes in 2017. But policymakers could offer some more clarity as to what could spur the Fed to accelerate its rate increase pace.Earnings on tap for Tuesday: Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) and food giant General Mills (GIS) report before the opening bell, while FedEx (FDX), Dow component Nike (NKE) and HealthEquity (HQY) are due after the closing bell.RELATED:Nike, FedEx, Lennar Earnings: Investing Action PlanStocks Limp, But IBD 50 Shows An Important SignalIndustry Group Leaders Set Up New Buy PointsDo These 7 Chip Leaders Deserve Spot On Your Watch List?Nike Expected To Log First Earnings Decline In Over 4 Years

A back-and-forth session saw stocks ever-so-slightly deepen their losses for the week, as an uncertain health care vote in the U.S. Congress undercut investor confidence.The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq ended effectively flat, with fractional declines. The S&P 500 trimmed 0.1%. Small caps were more upbeat, lifting the Russell 2000 to a 0.5%. gain.A warning from Ford Motor (F) that first quarter earnings will miss analyst targets by a wide margin, and uncertainty over the outcome of a congressional health care vote scheduled Thursday evening, set a wobbly tone for the day's trade. Markets pulled back more sharply after news reports said the vote on the American Health Care Act, which would repeal the Affordable Care Act, would be delayed until at least Friday due to a lack of support among lawmakers.About two thirds of the 30 Dow Jones industrial average stocks lost ground, with UnitedHealth Group (UNH) falling furthest, down 1%.  Nike (NKE) held the upside, rebounding nearly 3% and taking back a piece of Wednesday's 7% decline. Nike's loss Wednesday undercut its 58.52 buy point in a large saucer with handle by more than 8%, triggering an automatic sell rule.Five Below (FIVE), Herman Miller (MLHR) and PVH (PVH) all pounded out big gains after reporting results late Wednesday.Accenture (ACN) dropped 4% and took the worst loss among S&P 500 stocks. Centene (CENT) and FedEx (FDX) were close behind, down 4% and 3%, respectively.Among IBD 50 stocks, Criteo (CRTO) rolled up a 4% advance in light trade. The move took back two days of declines and left the stock just below Tuesday's intraday high and extended from a January breakout and a February rebound from 10-week support.Nutrisystem (NTRI) pressed ahead 2% in above-average trade. Shares are extended past a 50.10 buy point following a breakout from a short-stroke pattern last week.GameStop (GME), KB Home (KBH) and Micron Technology (MU) are among the names expected to report after the close.For Friday, February durable goods data are due out from the Commerce Department, researcher Markit releases its preliminary composite estimate of the economy for March and Baker Hughes (BHI)reports its weekly oil rig count.A long list of Federal Reserve officials is also lined up to speak during Friday's session, beginning with San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams before the market opens.RELATED:Stocks Slightly Higher Ahead Of Vote; Apple Acquires Start Up WorkflowApple Preps India iPhone For Production, Buys Workflow App Ford Sees Q1 Earnings Well Below Views In Latest Flat Tire For Industry

Stocks were lower early Wednesday, after dumping hard in the prior session. The Dow Jones industrial average lagged as Nike's (NKE) quarterly report weighed.The Dow Jones industrials shed 0.4%, the S&P 500 fell 0.3% and the Nasdaq composite edged 0.1% lower. The small-cap Russell 2000 was down 0.3%. Volume was higher across the board vs. the same time Tuesday.Shoe and apparel retailers, department stores and financials led the downside in today's stock market action, while steel, airfreight transporters and utilities outperformed. West Texas intermediate crude oil slid 1.2% to $47.66 a barrel.Nike gapped down and tumbled 6%, undercutting its 50-day moving average before finding support at its 200-day line. But it pared its gains to 0.3%. The stock remains well extended from a 118.12 handle buy point cleared in early January and near the 20% profit-taking range, which it briefly entered Tuesday. Apple on Tuesday introduced a red iPhone 7, cheaper iPad and video-sharing app.FedEx (FDX) rose 1.5% in fast trade as it continues working on a flat base with a 201.67 potential buy point. The profit drop was its first in four years.IBD 50 stock HealthEquity (HQY)  surged 4% in robust turnover, sending shares near a 49.35 entry in an eight-week consolidation. The health savings account administrator's Q4 results topped forecasts. But its full-year EPS outlook for 50-55 cents came in below views for 56 cents, while the midpoint of its $220 million-$225 million revenue guidance was higher than consensus estimates for $221.6 million.Also on the IBD 50, Momo (MOMO) rose 3% in heavy volume. The Chinese social network's stock is near its highs and in profit-taking range from a 23.96 handle buy point.Winnebago (WGO) gapped up sharply before paring its gains to 2%. The stock is 27% off its December high and is testing its 200-day line. Stocks were mixed after the opening bell, as markets felt for direction after a tough day of selling Tuesday.The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2%, the S&P 500 eased 0.1% and the Nasdaq rose 0.1%.Tuesday's losses angled the Dow industrial average, the Nasdaq, the S&P 500 and the Russell 2000 toward their first monthly decline since October. The Dow, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 all ended the session above their 50-day moving averages, but the Russell 2000 broke below its 50-day line after a four-day stint above that level of support.Overseas, Japan took the hardest hit among major indexes. The Nikkei 225 in Tokyo dumped 2.1% as the yen flexed to a four-year high vs. the dollar. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index lopped off 1.1%. The Shanghai Composite ended down 0.5%.European markets trimmed some losses in afternoon trade. London's FTSE 100 remained down down 0.8%. Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC 40 in Paris eased 0.4% apiece.Nike (NKE) and DuPont (DD) were the anchors dragging on the Dow. Nike groaned 6% lower after its fiscal third-quarter earnings topped estimates, but a 5% revenue gain just missed analyst targets and gross margins declined. The stock opened below its 50-day moving average and 6% below its 58.52 buy point.DuPont carved 0.7% lower, as chemical plays appeared to be in motion after PPG Industries (PPG) reportedly raised its offer for Dutch paint maker Akzo Nobel to $24.2 billion. PPG shares were down 0.6%. DuPont is attempting to complete a $130 billion merger with Dow Chemical (DOW). Dupont's shares are extended from a pullback to the 50-day line in January.Apple (AAPL) rose 0.6% and three of the four FANG stocks traded lower. Amazon.com (AMZN) slipped 0.2%. Netflix (NFLX) rose 0.6%.FedEx (FDX) tracked 3% higher after some optimistic full-year earnings guidance, stronger base rates and an uptick in commercial volume during the fiscal third quarter appeared to offset an earnings miss. The stock is forming a flat base with an alternative buy point at 198.70.Winnebago (WGO) punched up 3%. The motorhome maker reported a 37% rise in fiscal second-quarter earnings and a 64% revenue gain, both above analysts forecasts. The stock bounced from a drop to the 200-day moving average.Among IBD 50 stocks, HealthEquity (HQY) added more than 4% at the open. The health savings finance operation pre-announced better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings and revenue late Tuesday, but that came with full-year earnings guidance that missed consensus targets. Chardan Capital raised the stock's price target to 53 from 50 on Wednesday. HealthEquity is forming the right side of a cup base.Oil traded down more than 1% in early action, sending West Texas Intermediate back below $48 per barrel. Gold flattened near $1,246 an ounce. The dollar was mixed, down vs. the euro and up against the yen. The 10-year yield dropped 2 basis points to 2.40%.Economic reports expected 10 a.m. ET on Wednesday include existing home sales numbers for February.Meanwhile, housing prices showed no gain in January, according to the Federal Housing Finance Agency's House Price Index. That was below December's 0.4% increase, disappointing economist projections for an acceleration to 0.5% growth.  It was only the second month without a price increase since early 2012, the agency reported.RELATED:The Three Earnings Reports To Watch Today: Investing Action PlanFinancials, Small Caps Rocked As Market Outlook Weakens

But the big-cap earnings fireworks occur after the close, when FedEx (FDX) and Dow component Nike (NKE) are due to report. FedEx rose fractionally and Nike dipped. Nike shares are in buy range from a 58.52 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Marriott International (MAR) rose 1.7%. Gold traded flat near $1,233 an once. The dollar shifted lower vs. both the euro and the yen. The 10-year Treasury yield rose 2 basis points to 2.48%.Speaking in London this morning, New York Federal Reserve Bank President William Dudley argued banks need more carefully designed incentives, and said the scandal in which Wells Fargo (WFC) opened more than 2 million accounts without customer permission occurred largely because management failed to match employee incentives to the company's ethics policy.Kansas City Fed President Esther George and Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren are both scheduled to speak after the market closes this evening.Markets in Europe remained mixed in afternoon trade, with the FTSE 100 in London down 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX up 0.2% and the CAC 40 in Paris holding a 0.5% gain.Markets across Asia posted an active session Tuesday. In China, the Shanghai Composite climbed 0.3% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index swung up 0.4%, continuing its recent rebound. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ended 0.3% lower.RELATED:Nike Expected To Log First Earnings Decline In Over 4 YearsLennar Hails Post-Election Optimism As Revenue Growth AcceleratesFreeport-McMoRan Up, Copper Down On Mine RestartDow, S&P 500 Futures Rise; Here Comes The Fed, Again
