On Tuesday, Boeing, in its biennial World Air Cargo Forecast, said world air cargo traffic would double in the…

FedEx (FDX) shares shot to a new high Wednesday after it soundly beat fiscal first-quarter 2015 earnings and revenue estimates and reaffirmed its full-year guidance. The No. 2 U.S. package shipper, as it previously said it would, raised prices effective Jan. 5 by an average of 4.9%, and will also begin using size of packages for pricing. FedEx Q1 earnings…

Competing with Amazon isn't easy, but on Wednesday Target took sharp aim at e-commerce this holiday season with free shipping on online orders through Dec. 20 and in-store pickup within an hour. Target's (TGT) action marks the latest attempt from a major retailer to fend off online sellers as Santa's sleigh approaches. "Brick-and-mortar retailers are increasingly moving toward seamless omnichannel…
The market correction may be keeping a lid on stocks' potential gains; but the correction also helps keep some leaders near buy points.
The catch? All buys are riskier in this environment.

Facebook (FB) has been hovering in buy range since clearing a 76.09 flat-base buy point early last month. Volume was low at the breakout and the base-on-base was third stage, raising risk. But the stock hasn't triggered any sell signals since. Shareholders who bought at the social network's June breakout from a 66.57 cup-with-handle buy point are still up 16%.

FedEx (FDX) gapped up past a 155.41 buy point of a base-on-base pattern Sept. 17 in heavy turnover and rose as much as 6% to its Monday intraday high. But it reversed downward to close near its session low that day in above-average trade. The stock is still holding a 2% gain from the entry.

Profit growth stepped up the past two quarters from 0% to 15% to 37%. Analysts expect a 37% earnings gain for the current quarter. The package shipper's sales growth also accelerated the past two quarters from 3% to 4% to 6%, but that's below the double-digit levels seen in 2010-11.

Hanesbrands (HBI) cleared a 106.72 flat-base buy point Sept. 4 in volume 54% higher than usual. The stock had been weaving above and below the entry until Friday, when a 3% gain lifted it past 110. It remains above that level and is still in buy range at 3% from the third-stage-base buy point.

The socks, underwear and casual apparel maker shares the top Composite Rating, 98, in its 25-stock Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing group with G-III Apparel (GIII) and Under Armour (UA). It also gets high marks for its Earnings Per Share, Relative Strength and Sales + Profit Margins + ROE ratings.

Palo Alto Networks (PANW) climbed past a 102.55 three-weeks-tight buy point on Oct. 3 but has since eased to just below the entry. Volume was heavy at the breakout, a bullish sign. But the stock, like most others, is facing pressure with the market correction.The market correction may be keeping a lid on stocks' potential gains; but the correction also helps keep some leaders near buy points.The catch? Stocks rose Friday after the European Central Bank hinted at new stimulus measures to boost inflation. But the major averages ended off intraday highs.

The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.5%, and the S&P 500 was up 0.4%. Volume was mixed in the stock market today, rising 16% on the NYSE and falling 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Thursday, according to preliminary figures.
European Central Bank head Mario Draghi suggested that the ECB will introduce new stimulus measures at its Dec. 3 meeting.
Retailers, medical and apparel stocks led the upside, while data storage, energy and steel stocks underperformed.

Nike (NKE) led the Dow and the IBD 50, jumping 5% in heavy volume after announcing a 2-for-1 stock split, share buyback and a dividend increase late Thursday. The stock is well extended past a 117.82 buy point but has found support at the 50-day moving average.

Alaska Air (ALK) was also among the best-performing IBD 50 stocks. The regional airline climbed nearly 3%, in line with oil's plunge below $40 a barrel, as it nears an 82.88 buy point of a flat base. Hawaiian Holdings (HA) also rose nearly 3%. The carrier is just 1% off an all-time high and well out of buying range.

On the downside, Mentor Graphics (MENT) plunged 35% to a 52-week low after Mentor, a developer of software used to test electronic systems, issued a disappointing quarterly earnings report.Stocks rose Friday after the European Central Bank hinted at new stimulus measures to boost inflation. Stocks marched to fresh session highs Monday after bouncing back from a weak open.The Nasdaq climbed 0.6% and poked above its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500, which regained its 50-day line earlier, rose 0.4%. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average was also up 0.4%. But volume was tracking modestly lower across the board in the stock market today.Most leading stocks cleared buy points.M/I Homes (MHO) rose nearly 2% and cleared a 25.71 buy point in a flat base. This is its third time since April that it has cleared a buy point from a base. But the thinly traded issue did not get far the prior two times before settling into a new consolidation. Last month, the homebuilder delivered a 39% jump in Q2 earnings and a 15% gain in sales. Both marked another period of acceleration.Armstrong World Industries (AWI) rose more than 1% after shaking off more weakness. It cleared a 59.06 buy point from a big cup-with-handle base. It also cleared a 59 buy point from a smaller cup with handle. Armstrong makes floor products and ceiling systems.Elsewhere, D.R. Horton (DHI) didn't clear a buy point, but it rose 2% to its best levels in more than nine years. The homebuilder is featured in IBD Stock Analysis.Earlier, the National Association of Home Builders said that builder morale hit its highest levels since 2005.On the downside, NetEase (NTES) fell nearly 3%, extending last week's 15% nose dive on concerns over profit margins. Technically, the stock is still in a cup-with-handle pattern, but the correction in the handle is now 25%. Proper handles tend to correct 8% to 12%.

FedEx will be challenged in its fiscal first-quarter report to repeat the prior quarter's success as it grapples with legal issues, including drug-related charges. FedEx (FDX), the No. 2 U.S. package delivery service — which beat fiscal Q4 views in June after missing them in the prior two quarters — is slated to report fiscal Q1 earnings Wednesday morning. Stocks extended losses midday Thursday, a day after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. The S&P 500 fell 0.8%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq were each down 0.7%.
Volume was running higher on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared to the same time Wednesday.

Economic news was mixed, with unemployment claims falling a little less than expected in the week ended Dec. 12, while manufacturing in the mid-Atlantic region fell much more than expected in December. The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators rose 0.4% in November, down from the prior month's 0.6% increase but ahead of analysts' forecasts.
Mining and energy stocks were hit hardest in the stock market today on declines in oil and metals prices.
Newmont Mining (NEM), a Colorado-based miner of gold and silver, lost 8%, leading the S&P 500 lower. Oil transportation stock Oneok (OKE) also dropped about 8%.

Most IBD 50 stocks were lower, led by Global Payments (GPN), which fell more than 2% in heavy volume. The stock plunged 8% on Wednesday, slicing through its 50-day line, after agreeing to buy rival credit card payments processor Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.
Total System Services (TSS), another credit card payments processor in the IBD 50, fell 2.7% but remains well above a 48.18 buy point of a cup-with-handle base that it cleared in October.
But Chinese social media stock Weibo (WB) was a bright spot. It jumped more than 4% in heavy volume, closing in on a 20.80 buy point of a deep, cup-shaped base.

The stock boasts a rising Relative Strength line and an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A, indicating strong demand for the shares. The stock has more than doubled since falling to a low of 8.78 on Aug. 24.Stocks extended losses midday Thursday, a day after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. The number of stocks hitting 52-week highs dropped off sharply Thursday as the general market took a beating on geopolitical concerns. Some leading stocks such as Whiting Petroleum (WLL), Level 3 Communications (LVLT) and FedEx (FDX) turned tail from new highs, but a few HMOs held on to gains. UnitedHealth Group (UNH) rose 1.35, or nearly 2%, to 85.11 in…

Worldwide oil demand will grow by 1.4 million barrels per day in 2015, up from growth of 1.2 million this year, the International Energy Agency said Friday. Demand will be driven by 4.2% growth from China, up from 3.3% in 2014. Non-OPEC countries will boost supply by 1.2 million bpd, meeting most of the demand growth, with the U.S. and Canada accounting for two-thirds of that.
Here is a summary of top world and U.S. economic news for Friday, July 11, 2014.
Obama to business: Pay suppliers faster

The White House touted a new initiative to get major companies to speed up payments to small firms that serve as contractors. Among 26 companies involved are Apple (AAPL), Honda (HMC), Coca-Cola (KO), Walgreen (WAG), FedEx (FDX) and IBM (IBM). The program mirrors a federal government effort to pay contractors within 15 days, aiding cash flow and making it easier to grow.

 Canada's economy lost 9,400 jobs in June and the unemployment rate ticked up to 7.1%, Statistics Canada reported. The details were a bit better, with 33,500 full-time jobs added. Part-time jobs fell back after rising by 26,000 the prior month. Over the past year, job growth has averaged a tepid 6,000 per month.
Socialist to get key European economy post

Jean-Claude Juncker, who is widely expected to be confirmed as the new head of the European Commission next week, pledged to name a socialist as economic affairs commissioner to reward the center-left members of the coalition supporting him. The post has been held by a fiscal hawk.
 France's current-account deficit widened to $4.2 billion in May from $3.1 billion in April, as the goods deficit increased and the service surplus narrowed.

 Germany's inflation rate rose 0.4% in June from May, the Destasis national statistics office said. The annual inflation rate picked up to 1% from 0.6% in May. Inflation in the broader euro zone was just 0.5% in June. European Central Bank officials have said that low inflation in Germany makes it harder for other euro members to adjust wages and become more competitive economically.

 Hungary's consumer prices fell 0.3% in June from a year ago, amid lower food and energy prices. Hungary's central bank has been cutting its main interest rate for two years, from 7% to 2.2%, and further cuts are expected.

Stocks were trading slightly lower as the noon hour approached Wednesday, with the markets waiting to hear from the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee.

The policymaking committee concludes a two-day meeting with an announcement expected at 2 p.m. ET, followed by a press conference with Fed Chair Janet Yellen. The Fed is expected to leave interest rates near zero and to continue to wind down its bond-buying program. Investors will be parsing the Fed's statement for clues regarding its view of economic growth.
In the stock market today, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 were off 0.1%, and the Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.2%. Volume was running higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.
FedEx (FDX) jumped nearly 5% after reporting better-than-expected earnings.
Adobe Systems (ADBE) gapped up and was trading nearly 8% higher, also after a good earnings report.
Among IBD 50 stocks, 23 were up and 27 were down. The best performer was Irish drugmaker Shire (SHPG), up 3% to an all-time high. The stock broke out of a base Monday.

The worst performer was Alliance Fiber Optic (AFOP), which dropped nearly 7% and pierced its 50-day moving in above-average volume.Stocks were trading slightly lower as the noon hour approached Wednesday, with the markets waiting to hear from the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee.The policymaking committee concludes a two-day meeting with an announcement expected at 2 p.m. ET, followed by a press conference with Fed Chair Janet Yellen. The Fed is expected to leave interest rates near zero and to continue to wind down its bond-buying program. Investors will be parsing the Fed's statement for clues regarding its view of economic growth.In the stock market today, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 were off 0.1%, and the Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.2%. Volume was running higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.FedEx (FDX) jumped nearly 5% after reporting better-than-expected earnings.Adobe Systems (ADBE) gapped up and was trading nearly 8% higher, also after a good earnings report.Among IBD 50 stocks, 23 were up and 27 were down. The best performer was Irish drugmaker Shire (SHPG), up 3% to an all-time high. The stock broke out of a base Monday.The worst performer was Alliance Fiber Optic (AFOP), which dropped nearly 7% and pierced its 50-day moving in above-average volume.

A handful of leading stocks marked new highs, with some reversing from early lows to rally into new-high ground. GoPro (GPRO) vaulted 8.84, or 11%, in active volume to 90.94 — its fifth straight new high. The camera maker unveiled two new Hero4 models that can shoot ultrahigh-resolution 4K video, plus an entry-level camera priced at $129. Shares, up 82%…

FedEx (FDX) now faces money laundering charges, after federal prosecutors alleged Friday the company was paid with illegally obtained money to transport controlled substances from unlicensed Internet pharmacies."FedEx delivered controlled substances and prescription drugs from online pharmacies to individuals who subsequently died or accidentally caused the death of others," the indictment said, according to the AP.Shares fell 0.7% to 148.63 on the stock market today.The prosecutors claim that several people died of overdoses after receiving the drug shipments, but FedEx isn't being charged for the deaths. Still, the company could be fined $1.6 billion.FedEx said it would plead not guilty and that the demands law enforcement agencies are making on the company would cause customers to lose their right to privacy."FedEx is innocent of these and all of the charges filed in this matter," FedEx spokesman Patrick Fitzgerald said to the AP. "We will plead not guilty. We will continue to defend against this attack on the integrity of FedEx."Last month, the company was charged with conspiring to distribute prescription drugs to people who didn't have a doctor's approval, which is a violation of the Controlled Substances Act.Last year, UPS (UPS) had to pay $40 million in fines over similar allegations and has since changed its monitoring procedures.Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter at @IBD_GRich.

Stocks gave up much of their early gains going into the afternoon Wednesday and activity slackened as investors held their breadth in anticipation of the Federal Reserve's announcement on monetary policy at 2 p.m. ET.A shift in interest rates is not expected, but the wording of the Fed's announcement and comments from Fed chief Janet Yellen in a press conference afterward will be closely parsed.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were little changed. Volume was running considerably lighter on both exchanges, but that could change after the Fed's announcement.In the stock market today, steel producers were the hot industry group, with several of the top members gapping up on big volume.Nucor (NUE) raised guidance and rose 4%. U.S. Steel (X) announced strategic changes and gained 9%.Steel Dynamics (STLD) was up nearly 5%.Among IBD 50 stocks, 27 were higher, 23 were lower. The top performer was Chinese automobile website BitAuto (BITA), up nearly 3%. It's been undergoing a correction and is about 20% off its high.Another Chinese stock, YY Inc. (YY), a social media platform, was the worst performer, down 2%.FedEx (FDX) broke out of a flat base in huge volume and was up 3% after issuing a better-than-expected quarterly report. EPS rose 37% from a year ago. The stock has risen five straight days.Thinly traded Apogee Enterprises (APOG), which makes products for the construction industry, was up nearly 9% after posting earnings that were 67% higher than a year ago.
Stocks traded quietly higher Wednesday ahead of the Fed's policy statement at 2 p.m. ET.
The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq all rose 0.1%. Nasdaq volume was tracking about 16% lower than Tuesday's level. NYSE volume fell 5%.

In the stock market today, FedEx (FDX) gapped above a flat-base buy point of 155.41. Shares jumped nearly 4% after the company reported a 37% rise in quarterly profit. Sales growth accelerated for the second straight quarter, rising 6% to $11.68 billion.

Meanwhile, IBD's Building-Residential/Commercial group was one of the day's top performers, helped by strong earnings from Lennar (LEN). Shares gapped up and rose 6% after the company reported earnings and sales growth that topped expectations. Lennar was just below a buy point of 42.67.

Steel producers continued their recent string of outperformance. U.S. Steel (X) jumped 9% in strong volume after the company projected Q3 earnings significantly higher than the current consensus earnings-per-share estimates. Group peer Nucor (NUE) followed suit, gaining 3.5% in fast trade.

After a breakout over 117.35 Tuesday, railroad operator Kansas City Southern (KSU) extended gains, rising 3%. The company updated its 2014 earnings guidance Tuesday, saying it expects growth in the high teens. The Thomson Reuters consensus estimate is for annual earnings of $4.72 a share, up 19% from 2013.

Recovering from a frosty Q3, FedEx (FDX) drove home healthy results as the shipping giant reported fourth-quarter results Wednesday.
Earnings rose 15.5% to $2.46 per share, beating views by a dime, and revenue rose 3.2% to $11.8 billion, topping estimates of $11.66 billion.
FedEx shares jumped nearly 5% to 147 in late morning trade on the stock market today.

A severe winter season hurt FedEx and its main rival, UPS (UPS), in the previous quarter. But FedEx Ground Q4 revenue grew 8% to $3.01 billion, the company said, with 8% average daily volume growth, thanks to e-commerce business shipping goods from Amazon (AMZN), eBay (EBAY) and other online retailers large and small.
FedEx Freight Q4 revenue grew 12% from year-ago figures to $1.55 billion. FedEx Express rose slightly from last year to $7 billion in the most recent quarter, despite challenges from fuel pricing.
For the year ended in May, FedEx revenue rose 3% to $45.6 billion with earnings increasing 8% to $6.75 per share.

The Memphis-based company will hike up FedEx Ground prices in January 2015 as packages are charged by "dimensional weight" — i.e., by volume and weight instead of weight alone. FedEx Freight shipping prices were raised 3.9% in March, and FedEx Ground and FedEx Home Delivery prices were increased by an average of 4.9% at the beginning of 2014. UPS also recently announced similar plans.
The shipping company anticipates fiscal 2015 earnings of $8.50 to $9 per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect $8.75 per share for the year.

"We think (management's) willingness to issue bold guidance (especially the high end at $9) underscores the progress that has been made in turning around the ailing Express business," said Macquarie analyst Kelly Dougherty in a research note. "We expect more of the same solid performance at the highly profitable and high-ROIC (return on invested capital) Ground segment and continued improvement in Freight as evidence that FDX can fire on all cylinders in FY '15."

The average large-cap growth fund has been left in the dust by its small- and midcap growth counterparts as well as the broad stock market over the past 15 years. But the top-performing large-cap growth funds have excelled in that period, with several standing out year-to-date.

ClearBridge Aggressive Growth Fund has gained an average annual 8.74% the past 15 years vs. 4.35% for the S&P 500. Investors in the fund have seen a gain of 12.26% year-to -date, handily beating the S&P 500's 7.14%. Its recent top holdings included Biogen Idec (BIIB), Comcast (CMCSK) and SanDisk (SNDK).
Manning & Napier Equity Fund is up an average annual 7.96% for the past 15 years and is up 10.42% this year. Its recent holdings included Baker Hughes (BHI) and Apple (AAPL).

Vanguard Capital Opportunity , up an average annual 11.64% and up 9.77%, recently counted Biogen and FedEx (FDX) among its top holdings.The average large-cap growth fund has been left in the dust by its small- and midcap growth counterparts as well as the broad stock market over the past 15 years. Stocks churned out a mixed open Wednesday as earnings reports fueled some significant early moves.
The Nasdaq slipped 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.1%. The S&P 500 hung on to a fractional gain.

Investor attention on the stock market today was focused largely on the policy announcement expected from the Fed at 2 p.m. ET. Volume picked up ahead of the announcement, rising 16% on the Nasdaq and 12% on the NYSE compared with the same time Tuesday.

In stocks,Adobe Systems (ADBE) gapped up 9%, leading both the Nasdaq 100 and the S&P 500, after reporting better-than-expected results for its May-ended quarter late Tuesday. The stock cleared a 15-week pattern.

Industrial gas supplier Air Products & Chemicals (APD) popped 7% to a new high after confirming that it had hired Seifi Ghasemi, chief executive of Rockwood Holdings (ROC), to replace current CEO John McGlade, effective July 1. Air Products broke out of a flat base with a buy point of 124.50.

FedEx (FDX) delivered a 5% gain at the start of trade after fiscal fourth-quarter sales and earnings comfortably topped expectations. The stock broke out of a shallow cup-with-handle base with a 145.09 buy point.
Exxon Mobil (XOM) rose a fraction and oil prices showed no response to reports that Exxon had evacuated its employees from the oil-production region in southern Iraq.
Leading stocks managed a healthy start, with more IBD 50 stocks rising than falling as trade began Wednesday.
Shire (SHPG) rattled off a 2% gain to mark a new high in solid trade. The Ireland-based drugmaker is extended after a breakout Monday.

Another Irish drug firm, Actavis (ACT), added almost 2%. Stocks meandered ahead of the Federal Reserve's announcement on monetary policy, expected at 2 p.m. ET, as volume remained lower on both major exchanges.

Fed announcements typically roil the markets for an hour or two, until investors absorb whatever news emerges. The Fed's open market committee is expected to keep interest rates near zero and continue to wind down its bond-buying program.
Chairwoman Janet Yellen will hold a 2:30 p.m. ET press conference.
The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average were both down 0.1%. The S&P 500 was up a smidgen.

Amazon (AMZN) was set to announce its a smartphone, said to have 3D capabilities. It was up less than 1% in below-average volume as it works on a long consolidation.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) took its $53 billion bid for Botox-maker Allergan (AGN) directly to shareholders by launching a tender offer. Valeant was trading little changed just below its 200-day moving average as it tries to rise off the lows of a base. Businesses don't have the weather to kick around anymore. That has led analysts to expect improved but not spectacular profit and revenue growth as the second-quarter earnings season kicks off this week. Although the first quarter's abysmal gross domestic product decline of 2.9% was blamed largely on the polar vortex and its blizzards, Q1's 5.6% profit growth turned out better…

More than 6 million American children have been diagnosed with attention deficit disorder (ADD) or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), reports the Centers for Disease Control.Individuals with ADD or ADHD sometimes have trouble concentrating. They might get bored easily. They often daydream and tend to have powerful spikes in energy.Life in a classroom or a cubicle can be a drag for the ADD/ADHD sort. If those with ADD/ADHD stay sharp, though, they can have extraordinary careers.Count among those with ADD/ADHD Olympic swimmer Michael Phelps, Kinko's (FDX) founder Paul Orfalea and David Neeleman, who launched JetBlue (JBLU)."There seems to be a consistently higher level of creativity, a higher level of intelligence among people with ADD," said Kevin Ross Emery, author of  "Managing the Gift Of Your ADD/HD Child."The world has long benefited from great leaders who, Emery says, exhibited ADD/ADHD characteristics. Try composer Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and car pioneer Henry Ford. "I look at this as a gift, that, yes, has some challenges," Emery told IBD.Avoid this mistake: using ADD/ADHD as an excuse not to pursue dreams."Once we relate to it as disabled, we become disabled," Emery said. "We find excuses not to do things. It's easy to become lazy."Do you have ADD/ADHD? Excel by working in a different way:• Take breathers. "If you need to do something that is going to take a long period of time or intense concentration, start by breaking it up into smaller pieces," Emery said.Exercise — even a stroll around the department or block — helps.Or dig into a completely different project for a half-hour, then return to the original task.• Book it. "By setting short, 20- to 40-minute appointments with myself to make calls, write 600-word articles or finish reports for my growth-consulting work, I'm able to get much more done," said Mark Faust, an executive consultant and author of "Growth or Bust!"He was diagnosed with ADD as an adult but learned how to harness its creative benefits on the job. "Both ADD and ADHD can be transformed into a strength," he said.• Move and groove. Swimming, running, walking, rowing or other repetitive physical activities can up your focus, Emery finds. He calls them moving meditations. "You are engaging your body, but your mind goes to another place," he said.• Feed your brain. "ADHD can be debilitating if you are on a bad diet," Emery cautioned.To still your mind and body, he recommends cutting back on caffeine, alcohol and sugar. • Find the finish line. Due dates help Faust stay on task when he's tempted to go off-track. "Because of a deadline, I was able to write 90% of my 50,000-word book in two weeks," he said.• Mark it down. Checklists, notebooks and sticky notes help people with ADD/ADHD remember details and finish each step so they can accomplish their tasks."They have so much going on in their heads that it needs to be organized," Emery said. "Both ADD individuals and the people around them must learn to put things in writing."Managers with ADD/ADHD employees and those who live with them should remember to write a list of the steps involved in accomplishing an important task the first time."Put it on something that they have a habit of checking," Emery added, "such as their computer screen, the refrigerator or the television."

Many companies take pride in raising their dividend every year without a single miss. FedEx (FDX) missed revenue and earnings views for its third quarter ended Feb. 28 as severe winter weather trimmed operating income by $125 million.
But investors looked past the weather and gave the No. 2 package delivery company a pass, sending shares up slightly in morning trading.

Memphis, Tenn.-based FedEx reported earnings of $1.23 a share, 23 cents below the $1.46 analysts had forecast and flat with last year's same period. Views had already been cut by 5 cents since Friday.
Revenue rose 3% to $11.3 billion, below the $11.4 billion analysts had expected.
In a morning conference call, CEO Frederick Smith said "it was the toughest winter FedEx has ever operated in," adding that January and February were especially bad. "Let's hope for spring."

FedEx's results follow a poor showing from No. 1 shipper United Parcel Service (UPS), which reported a 5% drop in earnings for its December-ended quarter. UPS blamed bad weather in the U.S. for higher costs.
Weather's impact led FedEx to trim its full-year forecast to $6.55 to $6.80 per share, below the $6.89 forecast by analysts.
FedEx Express' $1.6 billion profit improvement plan "remains on track despite the near-term impact of weather," Chief Financial Officer Alan Graf said in the release.
The company said it entered into accelerated share-buyback agreements of $2 billion in the quarter.

Revenue in the company's core FedEx Express segment was down slightly from last year to $6.67 billion while FedEx Ground rose 10% to $3 billion, helped in part by higher online shipments from Cyber Week, which fell in the second quarter last year.

Shipper FedEx (FDX) will report third-quarter results Wednesday for a period that likely went through some highs and lows.The No. 2 package delivery company's December-through-February quarter included the holiday shopping season, notable for a surge in online sales. Cyber Monday fell in the first week in December instead of November.But the quarter also was marred by severe winter weather, which caused airline delays and roadway challenges in much of the country.Top shipper United Parcel Service (UPS), in its December-ending fourth-quarter report, said e-commerce shipments pushed volume up 6% worldwide but cited higher costs in the U.S. due to the bad weather. It also said higher volumes stressed its network, causing it to deploy more people and equipment. Earnings fell 5% vs. 2012's same quarter.Analysts expect FedEx, the No. 2 package delivery company after UPS, to report a 5% gain in sales vs. the earlier year to $11.45 billion.Earnings are seen growing a more robust 23% to $1.51 a share as the firm continues to execute on its profit improvement and cost reduction initiatives. FedEx also raised prices on some services, effective Jan. 6.In its second-quarter report, Memphis, Tenn.-based FedEx said its outlook assumes "continued moderate economic growth" and share buybacks. It raised earnings guidance for the full year to 8% to 14% growth from 7% to 13% previously.FedEx shares are down 5% this year. But UPS is down nearly 8%. IBD's Transport-Air Freight industry group is down 8% for the year. The group ranks No. 126 of IBD's 197 industry groups.

Most employees who complain about their bosses don't quit and start their own company. But that's what Peter Rose and James Wang did in 1981 when they got their freight-forwarding business off the ground. Seattle-based Expeditors International (EXPD) was one of the earliest logistics companies to tap into the Asia-to-U.S. freight-logistics market. It went public in 1984, ending the year…
Stock futures were nose up, adding to early gains ahead of Wednesday's open, as oil prices gained and European markets crept higher.
Dow futures doubled early gains to 35.9 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures showed a moderate 8.5 point advance. S&P 500 futures added 2.5 points.

Volume will be on investors' minds as trading gets underway on the stock market today. Tuesday's gains in weak trade were better than a sharp stick in the eye. But institutional investors would need to throw in their support for any upward motion to become convincing.
The other matter weighing on investors' minds will be any new insights from the Federal Open Market Committee's March 19 meeting, minutes for which are due out at 2 p.m. ET.
Early stocks action was brisk.

Alcoa (AA) stepped up 4% after reporting mixed first-quarter results late Tuesday. Earnings topped expectations, revenue didn't, and management projected growth across every business sector except gas turbines in 2014. The world's largest aluminum producer ended Tuesday 60% above an Oct. 3 low.

Constellation Brands (STZ) jumped more than 3% ahead of the open. The wine and spirits purveyor reported fourth-quarter earnings per share up 72%, better than forecasts or a 62% gain. Revenue rumbled up 86%, in line with expectations, and management boosted its full-year revenue guidance to above consensus estimates.
Constellation shares have been in a sizzling uptrend since a June 2012 breakout. The stock dropped 4% in strong trade Monday, to a test of its 50-day moving average.

Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) caved 9% before the bell. The maker of robotic surgical instruments, after Thursday's close, shaved its first-quarter revenue guidance to 13% below consensus views. Management said the number included a customer "trade-out," revenue deferred in preference for the company's newly released da Vinci Xi system. Excluding the trade-out, revenue would be down 20% year-over-year, and 8% below consensus views.
The stock has been climbing off a December low, working up the right side of a 14-month consolidation.
Across the Pacific, China's markets rose and Japan's tumbled for a second day. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index popped 1.1%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 swooned 2.1%, putting the index down 5% so far for the week.
In Europe, stocks were on positive ground exiting morning trade. London's FTSE 100 led the crowd with a 0.7% gain.

The dollar took back some of its recent losses vs. the yen. It held near its low for the week against the euro. Oil added a few more pennies, after rising 2% to above $102 a barrel Tuesday. Natural gas was also higher, and was up 3% so far this week. Gold eased, but remained positive for the week and was above $1,304 an ounce.

Later this morning, the Commerce Department turns over its February wholesale inventory numbers at 10 a.m. ET. The stock dropped 4% in strong trade Monday, to a test of its 50-day moving average.Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) caved 9% before the bell. The maker of robotic surgical instruments, after Thursday's close, shaved its first-quarter revenue guidance to 13% below consensus views. Management said the number included a customer "trade-out," revenue deferred in preference for the company's newly released da Vinci Xi system. Excluding the trade-out, revenue would be down 20% year-over-year, and 8% below consensus views.The stock has been climbing off a December low, working up the right side of a 14-month consolidation.Across the Pacific, China's markets rose and Japan's tumbled for a second day. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index popped 1.1%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 swooned 2.1%, putting the index down 5% so far for the week.In Europe, stocks were on positive ground exiting morning trade. London's FTSE 100 led the crowd with a 0.7% gain.The dollar took back some of its recent losses vs. the yen. It held near its low for the week against the euro. Oil added a few more pennies, after rising 2% to above $102 a barrel Tuesday. Natural gas was also higher, and was up 3% so far this week. Gold eased, but remained positive for the week and was above $1,304 an ounce.Later this morning, the Commerce Department turns over its February wholesale inventory numbers at 10 a.m. ET. An important weekly crude oil inventory estimate from the Energy Information Administration is on the docket at 10:30 a.m.
It's finally spring, but wintry weather is likely to dominate the upcoming earnings season.

S&P 500 earnings will grow just 1.2% vs. a year earlier, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. That would be the 10th straight quarter of single-digit growth and the slowest pace since Q3 2012. Revenue is expected to grow a slothlike 2.7% for the first three months of 2014.About two-thirds of companies typically top forecasts, so the final figures will likely be less grim — but still well below Q4's 9.9%."Nobody is expecting any fireworks," said Sheraz Mian, director of research at Zacks Investment Research.Companies have been quick to blame bad weather in lowering expectations. There have been about six negative preannouncements for every positive one, Thomson Reuters said.Consumer discretionary firms are expected to deliver 6.1% earnings growth, down from 14.5% projected at the start of 2014."That's one of the sectors that is really talking about the weather a lot," said Gregory Harrison, senior research analyst at Thomson Reuters. "People are staying home, not going out shopping."FedEx (FDX) missed estimates last month when it reported its fiscal Q3 ended Feb. 28, saying that unusually severe winter weather "disrupted operations, decreased shipping volume and impacted year-over-year operating income by an estimated $125 million."Not surprisingly, utilities are expected to benefit from the bad weather, with earnings seen up 7.7% and revenue 3.9%. It is the sole S&P 500 sector that wasn't revised downward for Q1, Harrison said.Telecom is the sector expected to show the best growth at 12.8%.Technology should report a tepid 2.5% gain. Apple (AAPL) should eke out EPS growth of less than 1%, while Intel (INTC), IBM (IBM) and Microsoft (MSFT) show declines. But Facebook (FB), added to the S&P 500 in December, should double EPS.Energy and materials sectors should report earnings declines, reflecting sluggish global demand, particularly in China and emerging markets.Financial earnings should drop 2.6% with revenue off 0.8%. Banks are about finished with profit-flattering loan-loss reserve releases. Many are laying off mortgage staff and selling off their commodities units.Multibillion-dollar legal settlements involving big banks such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM) haven't helped their bottom lines either. JPMorgan and Wells Fargo (WFC) will report Q1 results on April 11.Bank Of America (BAC) EPS likely fell 75% in Q1. The Charlotte, N.C.-based giant reports April 16."The biggest industry within the finance sector — banks — they don't really have much growth avenues right now," said Mian of Zacks Investment Research.Property and casual insurers are expected to take a beating — a 12% decline — likely due to inclement weather.Struggles in emerging markets such as Turkey and the ongoing political crisis in Ukraine certainly have weighed on investors, but haven't made a big impact on earnings, Mian said."If Russia had gotten out of hand or gets out of hand going forward and comes in the way of the emerging recovery in Europe, then it's potentially a problem for earnings," he said.Investors will be particularly interested in companies' guidance for evidence that earnings growth will heat up in the spring.Wall Street sees 8.5% earnings growth in Q2. Revenue should rise 3.7%, just so-so, but it would be the best in two years.
Extraordinary efforts by the United Parcel Service (UPS) to meet a last-minute rush of online orders during a compressed holiday season, along with bad weather, hurt fourth-quarter earnings.
The world's largest package delivery service anticipates Q4 earnings per share of $1.25. That's below last year's $1.32 and undershoots consensus estimates for $1.43.
UPS also trimmed its full-year EPS guidance to $4.57 from its prior outlook of $4.65-$4.85. Full Q4 and 2013 results are slated for release on Jan. 30.

Shares were down 2% on the stock market today. The company's stock rose at a robust rate last year and hit an all-time high close of 105 on Dec. 31. It's been consolidating this year and shares are down about 6% from the peak.
Rival FedEx (FDX) eased less than 1% Friday.
UPS added 30,000 more temps than planned as the holiday peak approached in December, for a total of 85,000, along with trucks and other equipment to meet a last-minute surge in deliveries.
On Dec. 23, UPS delivered more than 31 million packages. That was 13% above the year-ago peak day and the most ever for the company.
Additionally, a series of heavy storms on the East Coast and in the Midwest hampered delivery efforts, driving up costs further.
The shorter holiday season didn't help either. There were just 26 shopping days between Thanksgiving and Christmas. In 2012, there were 32 shopping days.

FedEx's (FDX) fiscal second-quarter earnings are projected to rise at the fastest clip in more than a year, though any guidance on holiday package volume could be a bigger gift to investors. The shipping giant is slated to report early Wednesday for the quarter that ended Nov. 30, just before the peak holiday period. The consensus of 31 analysts polled…
The Panama Canal's expansion project won't be finished for nearly two years. But East Coast ports already are spending heavily to prepare for megacontainer ships from Asia bypassing West Coast stops.

The canal, which opened in 1914, is undergoing a $5 billion revamp to let more and much-larger ships pass through. Currently many giant vessels must unload hauls destined for the eastern half of the U.S. at West Coast ports. Now big ports on the Gulf and East Coasts are hoping to attract a flood of new business.
Many regional trucking companies and those hauling medium- sized shipments stand to benefit, said Rick O'Dell, CEO of Georgia-based trucking firm Saia Inc. (SAIA)

Of the 70% of ocean container traffic that lands on the West Coast today, as much as 30% could be diverted to the East and Gulf Coasts once the Panama Canal is expanded, according to various industry sources.
"It's going to be a very meaningful impact when you have this much shift of freight," O'Dell said.
Saia competes with FedEx (FDX) and Con-way (CNW), among others. Some of its biggest customers are Lowe's (LOW) and Wal-Mart (WMT).
Short-Haul A Big Winner?

One example of new efficiencies post-canal expansion: Wal-Mart's distribution center in central Florida would be better served when goods from Asia are offloaded at, say, the Port of Miami rather than in California, he said. Goods wouldn't have to be transported across the country, saving on costs.
Saia, which claims to be the No. 8 U.S. trucking company, should see "meaningful" increases in tonnage hauled from its current annual growth in the low-single digits, O'Dell says.

It operates truckloads of medium-sized shipments from multiple customers. It's a "less than truckload" operator, as opposed to full truckloads, which typically move one kind of product from one customer.
Truckers in the West shouldn't drive off a cliff, however. Goods destined for the Western U.S. will still go through Pacific ports.
When Iowa-based Heartland Express (HTLD) said Nov. 12 that it acquired Seattle-based Western carrier Gordon Trucking, its stock soared 21%.
Half of Cargo 'At Risk'

West Coast ports aren't sitting back. The ports of Los Angeles and nearby Long Beach — the top-two U.S. ports by volume — have multibillion-dollar infrastructure improvements underway to keep their competitive edge. They handle more than 40% of goods that come into the the U.S., most of it from Asia.

About half of the goods coming into those ports are moved by truck within California and adjoining states such as Nevada and Arizona. But the other half, largely discretionary goods, are taken by rail to the Midwest and points farther east, said Port of L.A. spokesman Phillip Sanfield.
That 50% of cargo moving farther east is "at risk" when larger container ships can use the Panama Canal to travel to East and Gulf ports instead, he said.

"We take the Panama Canal widening as just another competitive threat," Sanfield said. He noted that Canadian and Mex ican ports are chipping away at cargo going into the L.A.-Long Beach port complex.
Meanwhile, imports from Asia have slowed, flattening the once double-digit volume growth at the Southern California ports to 1% to 2% the last couple of years.

A wider canal won't "supercharge the water," shortening the time it takes ships to get through, Sanfield says. Transit times from Asia would still be shorter for goods dropped off at West Coast ports and then taken overland to the East Coast than if they were to go through the Panama Canal to East Coast ports.
Using the canal might be cheaper, but usage fees for the new, wider lane haven't been set yet.

After the Panama Canal project is finished, shippers "will optimize delivery to ports on the East Coast and Gulf Coast to get closer to their destinations," O'Dell says. That shift — getting closer to end deliveries — will have a more positive impact on truckers than rails, he added.
The West Coast's big port lock-down in 2002 was a "wake-up call" for big shipping and freight owners to pursue a port-diversification strategy, said transportation consultant Tony Hatch.
But larger ships mean larger loads and fewer stops, not more, Hatch says. He sees a shakeout.

"Not all ports will see the bigger ships. There will be winners and losers," he said. New York/New Jersey and Norfolk,Va., are at the top of his winners' list, followed by Savannah, Ga., and perhaps Miami. The latter will benefit even if it lands just one new megaship.
Miami's Panama Bet
In Miami, the price tag to deepen the port, improve the rail link and build a tunnel for trucks comes to around $2 billion.

Vice President Joe Biden recently visited the Panama Canal's construction site. He met with President Ricardo Martinelli to thank Panama for the economic opportunities that will open for the U.S. when the new lane is opened.
Telling was who tagged along: the mayors of Philadelphia, Baltimore and Atlanta, Sen. Johnny Isakson, R-Ga., and Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz, D-Fla.
Biden said that more than two-thirds of Panama Canal transits begin or end in America. U.S. exports will also benefit, he said.

"A bigger canal will allow the world's largest ships to connect from the eastern half of the Western Hemisphere to the growing markets of Asia," he said. "Many of our East Coast and Gulf of Mexico ports — and the rail lines, canals and highways that feed them — will see a major spike in traffic."

He sent a special message to Houston, which he also visited: "The expansion is expected to send five times as many containerized exports from the Port of Houston through the Panama Canal by the year 2035."
Think exports of liquified natural gas from U.S. shale fields, for one.

But one potential major LNG player on the Gulf Coast, Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA), just backed away from a $20 billion gas-to-liquids plant there, citing cost concerns.The Panama Canal's expansion project won't be finished for nearly two years. The No. 2 U.S. package delivery company reported a 13% rise in fiscal Q2 earnings to $1.57 a share, missing the consensus for $1.64. That was the second straight quarter of deceleration. The term creative destruction is thrown around a lot, but Amazon truly ushered in a new industry while disrupting several others. It wrote the book on e-commerce, spreading from its bookselling roots into a behemoth that brought down brick-and-mortar rivals with superior service and execution, to linking new and unlikely businesses in novel ways.

Amazon (AMZN), founded in 1994 by CEO Jeff Bezos in his garage, started as an online bookseller and sold its first book in July 1995. Customers could get rare books they couldn't find anywhere else and current titles more cheaply than from rivals.
The e-commerce firm expanded into electronics, toys, music and home improvement products and went public in 1997.
Amazon sales exploded from well under $1 million in 1995 to $2.76 billion in 2000 and $74.5 billion last year.
Shares leapt 8,526% from their 1997 low to their initial December 1999 peak.
Building The Brand
Amazon wasn't making money — but that was the plan. Bezos realized from the start that building the brand, infrastructure and market share was crucial, so his strategy was to forgo profits for years.

"There's nothing about our model that can't be copied over time," Bezos told Inc. magazine in 1997. "But you know, McDonald's got copied. And it still built a huge, multibillion-dollar company. A lot of it comes down to the brand name. Brand names are more important online than they are in the physical world."
While Bezos is hailed as a visionary now, nobody wanted to hear about money-losing Internet companies after the dot-com bust. Losses continued to mount while sales growth slowed to 13% in 2011.
Shares crashed 95% from December 1999 to October 2001.
In 2000, Ronald Unkefer, CEO of West Coast electronics retailer Good Guys, told IBD that he wasn't worried about Amazon, saying that Amazon and consumer electronics don't mix.
But Amazon sales growth ramped back up and the company soon became profitable.

Within a few years, Good Guys was out of business, followed by Circuit City and bookseller Borders. Barnes & Noble (BKS) and Best Buy (BBY) are often derided as de facto Amazon showrooms and are still trying to adapt. In February, Best Buy's CEO said his company was an "online first" retailer.
Amazon shares rose 7,306% from their 2001 low to their March 2014 peak — or 31,050% for their entire run.
The key to Amazon's success was in creating a no-hassle, no-worry experience, building trust with customers in the new realm of online shopping.

"Amazon looks like a highly efficient company today," Mark Mahaney, an analyst at RBC Capital Markets, told IBD. "But they slogged through years and years building up customer base and product offerings."
The company offers no-hassle returns, one-click ordering and a customer call center with a minimal wait time.

"Customers want to go somewhere they trust," Raymond James analyst Aaron Kessler said. "There aren't many companies you would save your credit card information at. But you would at Amazon. It's frictionless to shop there."
Recent data breaches at retailers like Target (TGT) and Neiman Marcus highlighted the risk. But Amazon so far hasn't had any major security problems despite its high volume of customer traffic.
Craig Berman, VP of Global Communications, said in an email that Amazon takes "protection of data very seriously" and said it works every day to keep promises to customers to keep their trust.
Amazon's online reviews gave users the chance to rate and describe products that gave other potential customers the sense they were feeling out the product before buying it.

Low prices also kept customers coming back. Until recently, Amazon didn't collect sales tax, a sizable advantage over brick-and-mortar stores. Amazon also doesn't have the expense of running a physical store with limited options and quantities.

But building up warehouses and distribution networks isn't cheap and can't be done quickly, instead it is an ongoing process. Amazon's massive infrastructure spending — still ongoing — is a key reason why profitability took a long time and has continued to remain spotty.
Getting products from Amazon warehouses to its customers also has been an enormous lift to UPS (UPS) and FedEx (FDX). Both have seen their delivery businesses explode with Amazon and e-commerce.

Amazon also added third-party sellers to its site, giving smaller retailers the opportunity to reach a large audience for a fee, while allowing customers to find nearly everything imaginable under one website.

"Customers can add a Kindle book, headphones, a cocktail dress and diapers into a single shopping cart," Berman said. "Avoiding long checkout lines or the fight for a parking space are a couple of reasons Amazon customers love the convenience of shopping online."
Free Shipping
Amazon offers free shipping for orders over $35. That hits margins but in return gives Amazon a revenue boost.

Amazon launched its Prime service in 2005, offering customers free 2-day shipping and lower prices on one-day shipping for a flat yearly rate, encouraging the consumers to buy even more products from the company.
Amazon has had an uncanny ability to see new opportunities.
In the early aughts, Amazon ran into computer capacity problems. When it began to standardize its retail computing online, the company realized it could offer virtual servers as a service.
Bezos explained the decision to Wired in 2011:

"The common question that gets asked in business is, why? That's a good question, but an equally valid question is, why not? This is a good idea, we have a lot of skills and assets to do this well, we're already going to do it for ourselves — why not sell it, too?"

Amazon Web Services became part of the vanguard of the cloud-computing movement. Its clients include startups like Airbnb, Pinterest and Spotify that could start small and scale up as needed. AWS also serves established companies like General Electric (GE), Netflix (NFLX) and Unilever (UN).
"AWS allows customers to move away from managing technology infrastructure so they can focus on investing and innovating for their own customers," Berman said.
Amazon doesn't break out revenue from Amazon Web Services, but analysts estimate it topped $1.5 billion in 2012. The contribution to the bottom line may be even more important.

"Profit is something to worry about but Amazon at its core is a retailer," Mahaney said. "With Amazon you should expect single-digit operating margins, but when they get into other segments like ad revenue and Amazon Web Services then you see higher margins."
Making Lemonade

Amazon has largely given up trying to avoid collecting state and local sales taxes. But once again, it's turning lemons into lemonade. No longer minimizing physical presences to avoid tax issues, Amazon is building more distribution centers, close to big cities, as it pushes toward next-day and same-day delivery. The move still puts pressure on brick-and-mortar retailers to adapt.
The company is also branching out into online grocery with its AmazonFresh service, available in Southern California, San Francisco and Seattle.
Mahaney doesn't see a new online rival to Amazon in the next five to 10 years.
"Amazon is extremely hard to replicate. It would be extremely expensive to set up distribution centers and master logistics," he said.
Amazon introduced the Kindle e-reader in 2007, followed by full-fledged tablets.

Amazon hopes consumers fill up the devices with e-books, videos and other media from its site. And if users are buying media from Amazon, they are more likely to also buy other goods such as diapers or clothing.
"Amazon has an extremely competent management team that have been able to see around the corner," Mahaney said. "For example the digital reading Kindle, that was far seeing on their part."

In March, Amazon announced it would raise the annual membership fee of its Prime service to $99 from $79, but customers are still signing up for the service to take advantage of shipping and other perks, like online video streaming.
Lumping Amazon Instant Video, a service similar to Hulu and Netflix, and free shipping into the same deal doesn't seem to make a lot of sense up front.
But Amazon has the ability to see what a wide range of customers might want and then deliver.
On April 2, it unveiled its Amazon Fire TV, a $99 streaming video set-top box. Recent reports say Amazon will launch a smartphone this summer.

But despite its continued long-term focus, Amazon delivered strong profit growth in 2013. And analysts expect triple-digit EPS gains over the next three years.The term creative destruction is thrown around a lot, but Amazon truly ushered in a new industry while disrupting several others. It wrote the book on e-commerce, spreading from its bookselling roots into a behemoth that brought down brick-and-mortar rivals with superior service and execution, to linking new and unlikely businesses in novel ways. Customers could get rare books they couldn't find anywhere else and current titles more cheaply than from rivals.The e-commerce firm expanded into electronics, toys, music and home improvement products and went public in 1997.Amazon sales exploded from well under $1 million in 1995 to $2.76 billion in 2000 and $74.5 billion last year.Shares leapt 8,526% from their 1997 low to their initial December 1999 peak.Building The BrandAmazon wasn't making money — but that was the plan. The contribution to the bottom line may be even more important."Profit is something to worry about but Amazon at its core is a retailer," Mahaney said. "With Amazon you should expect single-digit operating margins, but when they get into other segments like ad revenue and Amazon Web Services then you see higher margins."Making LemonadeAmazon has largely given up trying to avoid collecting state and local sales taxes. But once again, it's turning lemons into lemonade. No longer minimizing physical presences to avoid tax issues, Amazon is building more distribution centers, close to big cities, as it pushes toward next-day and same-day delivery. The move still puts pressure on brick-and-mortar retailers to adapt.The company is also branching out into online grocery with its AmazonFresh service, available in Southern California, San Francisco and Seattle.Mahaney doesn't see a new online rival to Amazon in the next five to 10 years."Amazon is extremely hard to replicate. It would be extremely expensive to set up distribution centers and master logistics," he said.Amazon introduced the Kindle e-reader in 2007, followed by full-fledged tablets.Amazon hopes consumers fill up the devices with e-books, videos and other media from its site. And if users are buying media from Amazon, they are more likely to also buy other goods such as diapers or clothing."Amazon has an extremely competent management team that have been able to see around the corner," Mahaney said. "For example the digital reading Kindle, that was far seeing on their part."In March, Amazon announced it would raise the annual membership fee of its Prime service to $99 from $79, but customers are still signing up for the service to take advantage of shipping and other perks, like online video streaming.Lumping Amazon Instant Video, a service similar to Hulu and Netflix, and free shipping into the same deal doesn't seem to make a lot of sense up front.But Amazon has the ability to see what a wide range of customers might want and then deliver.On April 2, it unveiled its Amazon Fire TV, a $99 streaming video set-top box. Recent reports say Amazon will launch a smartphone this summer.But despite its continued long-term focus, Amazon delivered strong profit growth in 2013. And analysts expect triple-digit EPS gains over the next three years.

While Amazon.com (AMZN) got a lot of press this month talking up future delivery by drones — and FedEx makes some fun of that — FedEx and United Parcel Service are trucking ahead with ways to optimize human drivers. Robots figure in at the shippers' sorting facilities, but it's mostly less sexy technology that's powering savings and helping the companies…
U.S. online retail sales this holiday season once again outperformed offline retail, though reports were mixed as to whether online sales would meet projections of 14% to 15% growth.

Late Thursday, market tracker ComScore said U.S. online sales were up 10% Nov. 1 through Sunday. While that's far ahead of offline retail growth, ComScore has forecast 14% growth for November-December. And Forrester Research has forecast 15% growth.

But U.S. online sales jumped 16.5% on Christmas Day vs. last Dec. 25, says IBM Smarter Commerce, an e-commerce unit of IBM (IBM) that tracks the websites of more than 800 U.S. retailers. The IBM unit says year-over-year sales rose more than 37% for the Friday-through-Sunday before Christmas.

The number of online orders among 70 retailers tracked by e-commerce services company ShopVisible from Nov. 1 through Wednesday rose 13% vs. the year-earlier period, with revenue rising 15% in that span.
Total U.S. retail spending this holiday is tracking up 2.4% to 3.9%, depending on the source.

Online sales maybe were a little too good. Some orders were not delivered before Christmas because a higher-than-expected volume of late-season orders overwhelmed delivery companies UPS (UPS) and FedEx (FDX). Goods bought online at Amazon.com (AMZN) and Wal-Mart (WMT) were among the late deliveries.

Overstock.com (OSTK) says about 200 customers didn't receive orders by Christmas because of the shipping backups, and company representatives contacted those customers on Tuesday and Wednesday to explain, Overstock CEO Patrick Byrne told IBD.
Byrne says the delivery glitches should not affect future holiday e-commerce business, though not everyone was appeased.
"There were two angry customers," Byrne said. "They had both ordered perfume, so presumably you can't give your girl perfume after Christmas."

Bad weather also hurt deliveries, UPS spokeswoman Natalie Black told Reuters on Wednesday. UPS projected 132 million deliveries last week "and obviously we exceeded that," Black told Reuters, without disclosing a figure.
Amazon said it would refund shipping charges for all late deliveries and give those affected $20 gift cards.
'Decent Holiday Season'
The numbers indicate that the cybersales growth engine remains intact, says Will Devlin, senior marketing manager for ShopVisible.
"It was a decent holiday season overall for our clients, and that is pretty much in line with what we have seen from other reports out there," Devlin said.
Mobile devices accounted for nearly half of all online traffic on Christmas Day, a record, says Jay Henderson, strategy director for IBM Smarter Commerce.

"As people winded down their conversations with family, they pulled out their mobile devices and were thinking about what items they might return, or were looking for some post-Christmas deals," he said.

More than 1 million consumers worldwide signed up for Amazon.com's Amazon Prime loyalty program in the third week of December, the No. 1 etailer said Thursday. For $79 a year, Amazon Prime provides free two-day shipping and other perks.
"The entire 2013 holiday season was the best ever for Amazon," the company said in a release.
Traffic growth at online seller Overstock.com is up 10% this holiday season, which CEO Byrne says equates to bigger growth.
"That is fine for us because we are getting more revenue out of each visitor," he said. "We are getting better conversions and a higher average order size."
Sales at Wayfair.com, an online retailer of home goods, jumped 50% from Nov. 1 through Christmas Day vs. the year-earlier periond, says CEO Niraj Shah.
"It wasn't a great holiday season for everybody, but I think you're going to see that e-commerce was the stand-out success," Shah said.

NoMoreRack.com also reports a big holiday season, with sales of $144.1 million from Oct. 15 through Dec. 25, up 180% from the year-earlier period. Its Christmas Day sales rose 108% to $762,651, says company CEO Deepak Agarwal. In 1917, Gen. John Pershing reviewed troops training for World War I, berated their general for incompetence and turned to leave.

"George Marshall then did something that could have cost the mere captain his promising career, laying his hand on Pershing's arm and insisting that he be heard out about the hurdles they had faced," wrote Thomas Ricks in "The Generals."
Rather than finish Marshall's rise, it perpetuated it.

Pershing admired the young officer's boldness and brought him to headquarters. Marshall would go on to become the top Allied commander during World War II, secretary of state at the start of the Cold War, and defense secretary during the Korean War.
Rise In Pennsylvania
Marshall (1880-1959) grew up in rural Uniontown, Pa. His father had moved there in the 1870s, after fighting for the Union, to make a fortune in coke, a coal-derived fuel for iron smelting.
A shy boy, George didn't like to study, so his prospects seemed limited. But to prove everyone wrong, he worked hard to qualify for entry into the Virginia Military Institute.
Arriving late and weak after a bout with typhoid fever, he found he wasn't any good at drilling. Through self-discipline and practice, however, he mastered it and became the class leader.

"Getting a commission was not easy, but he managed to get past numerous guards and obstacles to burst in on a meeting of both the chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee and President McKinley and eventually got his chance to take the exam," Mark Stoler, author of "George C. Marshall: Soldier-Statesman of the American Century," told IBD. "There were 10,000 applications for 142 new second lieutenants, and Marshall had an 84.8% average largely due to his perfect scores in the heavily weighted categories of physique and moral character and background."
From 1902 to 1916, Marshall served as a junior officer in overseas posts, impressing his peers and superiors on the way to becoming a captain at age 35.
After the Spanish-American War of 1898, the Army's infantry and cavalry school at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., became a hotbed of reform, and Marshall studied and taught classes there from 1908 to 1910.
He had a chance to utilize his knowledge in Europe after America entered World War I in 1917.
Continental Surge

Rising to colonel, Marshall played a key role in planning the American offensive in the Meuse-Argonne sector of France in September 1918. He helped direct 220,000 troops off the front line, sending in 600,000 while delivering 3,000 artillery pieces and 900,000 tons of supplies, an unprecedented logistical feat.
He was so successful as Pershing's aide, he was passed over for promotions that favored officers on the battlefield.

"However, when Pershing became Army chief of staff in 1921, Marshall had the opportunity to interact with civilian authorities and meet and learn from individuals in both military and political spheres, giving him an education unavailable in any other position," said Stoler. "Pershing was often away and Marshall assumed more and more responsibilities."
Toward Another War
By the time Pershing retired in 1924, budget cuts had brought the Army head count to 132,000 because not many people thought another war would hit America.
Marshall was one of the survivors, reverting to lieutenant colonel and becoming assistant commandant of the Infantry School at Fort Benning, Ga., in 1928.
With 150 future generals passing through the school as students and 50 as instructors in his four years there, Marshall virtually created the World War II high command.
In the summer of 1938, Marshall was ordered to D.C. to head up the war plans division for Malin Craig, who had replaced Douglas MacArthur as Army chief of staff.

President Franklin Roosevelt saw that Marshall was unafraid to speak truth to power. A year later he promoted Marshall, by now a three-star general, over 33 more senior officers to be a four-star Army chief of staff.
The new military boss put his boot down hard, relieving commanders who had the wrong mindset or were incompetent, ultimately forcing out 600 before the U.S. entered World War II in 1941.

Otherwise, the Army was hardly ready after Pearl Harbor, with only 197,000 soldiers. Marshall oversaw a boom to 8.3 million troops in three years — doing so with directness in his dealings with Congress.

"Marshall's willingness to tell the unvarnished truth, even when it hurt the case he was trying to make, made him trusted by everyone," said Brian Shaw, president of the Marshall Foundation in Lexington, Va. "He was also always the best-prepared person at the table, knowing the issues inside and out."
Marshall's lesson is that consistent honesty builds credibility.
He was the logical commander for the invasion of Normandy, which would start June 6, 1944, so Roosevelt offered him the job.

"His Victorian values refused to allow him to put his self-interest above country, so he told the president to do what was right for the United States," said Stoler, who is editing volumes 6 and 7 of "The Papers of George Catlett Marshall." "Roosevelt said he couldn't sleep at night if Marshall were out of the country and so selected his protege, Dwight Eisenhower, to plan the invasion."

On Dec. 16, 1944, Marshall became the first American promoted to the five-star rank, the newly created general of the Army. He was "the true organizer of Allied victory," lauded British Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

Marshall stepped down as Army chief at the end of the war in 1945 and for two years tried to negotiate a peace between warring parties in China. In 1947, President Truman made him secretary of state to manage the emerging threats.

"In two years he established the containment policy of the Cold War and, as part of it, the European Recovery Program, the Marshall Plan for which he received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1953," said Stoler in his audio course, "The Skeptic's Guide to U.S. History."
Marshall left the State Department in January 1949, but a year later Truman called the 69-year-old back as defense secretary amid the Korean War.
Marshall retired for good in 1951.
Legacy

"Marshall's rise came at a time when the Army needed more professional management, and his lessons are applicable to business today," said Shaw. "Among other traits, he was very good at analyzing current trends to be able to predict the next crisis. Everyone from FedEx (FDX) founder Fred Smith to leadership studies pioneer Warren Bennis has urged managers to emulate his example."

Stoler wrote: "Marshall's leadership qualities, self-control, sense of honor and duty, and apparent lack of personal ambition were so extraordinary that virtually every individual with whom he worked commented on them in hushed tones of veneration. His character and accomplishments were so exceptional that he is placed in the company only of George Washington when historical parallels are used."In 1917, Gen. John Pershing reviewed troops training for World War I, berated their general for incompetence and turned to leave."George Marshall then did something that could have cost the mere captain his promising career, laying his hand on Pershing's arm and insisting that he be heard out about the hurdles they had faced," wrote Thomas Ricks in "The Generals."Rather than finish Marshall's rise, it perpetuated it.Pershing admired the young officer's boldness and brought him to headquarters. Marshall would go on to become the top Allied commander during World War II, secretary of state at the start of the Cold War, and defense secretary during the Korean War.Rise In PennsylvaniaMarshall (1880-1959) grew up in rural Uniontown, Pa. His father had moved there in the 1870s, after fighting for the Union, to make a fortune in coke, a coal-derived fuel for iron smelting.A shy boy, George didn't like to study, so his prospects seemed limited. Amazon.com (AMZN) said Monday it's teamed up with the U.S. Postal Service to launch a service that provides nationwide deliveries for Amazon Prime members on Sundays.

The service, which kicks off this week in New York and Los Angeles, aims to make Amazon Prime membership more attractive to shoppers. The move, timed for the holiday season, comes at the expense of Amazon's mainstay United Parcel Service (UPS), which doesn't deliver on Sundays. FedEx (FDX) offers only limited Sunday service.
Prime members who pay Amazon's $79 annual fee for free two-day shipping on eligible items and media access can now get Sunday deliveries in the LA and NYC at no extra charge.

Amazon and the U.S. Postal service plan to expand Sunday deliveries to a large portion of the U.S. population in 2014, offering it in Dallas, Houston, New Orleans, Phoenix and other large U.S. cities.
Amazon stock, which late last month touched an all-time high of 368.40, was up a fraction in midday trading in the stock market Monday, near 352. Amazon stock is up 40% this year.

The deal is a shot in the arm for the ailing U.S. Postal Service, which faces mounting financial losses and tumbling physical letter delivery volumes because of digital alternatives. Post office package deliveries, in comparison, are surging.

"As online shopping continues to increase, the Postal Service is very happy to offer shippers like Amazon the option of having packages delivered on Sunday," Postmaster General Patrick Donahoe said in the press release announcing the pact. "With this new service, the Postal Service is now delivering packages seven days a week in select cities. Customers can expect the same reliable and valued service that the Postal Service currently provides."
Amazon's Dave Clark, vice president of worldwide operations and customer service, said in the release that Amazon customers "will love the additional convenience."

Amazon has recently taken other steps to make Prime membership more attractive. On Oct. 22, it raised its minimum order size for non-Prime free shipping to $35 from $25. It was the first such increase in a decade. Analysts say the move was aimed at offsetting Amazon's subsidized shipping costs and encouraging more consumers to pay the $79 annual fee for Prime membership.
Related: Amazon 'Thanks' FAA Via A Kindle Discount Offer.

The major indexes lost ground in pre-market action Wednesday, as investors took in reports on housing and producer prices.
Nasdaq 100, S&P 500 and Dow futures all traded lower ahead of the opening bell.

Housing starts tumbled 10% to a seasonally adjusted rate of 593,000 in May. That was well below the 655,000 starts predicted for the month, and also down from 672,000 in April. The expiration of the government's tax credit program helped cause the shortfall.
Permits for new construction also fell, missing economists' views.
Meanwhile, the Labor Department's Producer Price Index sank 0.3% in May, a smaller drop than the 0.5% decline pegged by economists, though a bigger pullback than the 0.1% dip seen in April.
Excluding volatile food and energy costs, prices rose 0.2%  higher than the 0.1% uptick projected by economists and matching April's result.

The Federal Reserve was slated to release data on May industrial production and capacity utilization at 9:15 a.m. EDT. Analysts expect utilization rose to 74.4% in May from 73.7% a month earlier. They expect production stayed flat at 0.8%.

FedEx (FDX) issued a conservative estimate for its new fiscal year. The package delivery firm forecast earnings of $4.40 to $5 a share for fiscal 2011, below analysts' consensus view of $5.05.
